Title_x: "Great work environment that accommodates life's busy schedule."
Pros_x: Flexible Schedule, Good Pay, Friendly Atmosphere, 50% Food Discount up to 4 people when dining at any Brinker restaurant, Opportunities for Advancement
Cons_x: Difficult to maintain hours during slow seasons, Company has no sustainability program and does not appear to want one
Advice to Management_x: Listen to employee concerns and voice them to higher levels of management. Also, take every opportunity to cross train as many employees as you can. This strengthens the restaurant as a whole, means less empty shifts during illness or emergencies and allows employees to maximize their salaries by switching roles as needed.
Title_y: "One of the best jobs I have ever had."
Pros_y: Great Benefits, quality of life balance +
Cons_y: Some late nights. Long shifts. Lots of stress in high volume restaurants.
Advice to Management_y: I was treated very well by all...

Advice to Management_x: Listen to employee concerns and voice them to higher levels of management. Also, take every opportunity to cross train as many employees as you can. This strengthens the restaurant as a whole, means less empty shifts during illness or emergencies and allows employees to maximize their salaries by switching roles as needed.

Advice to Management_x: Listen to employee concerns and voice them to higher levels of management. Also, take every opportunity to cross train as many employees as you can. This strengthens the restaurant as a whole, means less empty shifts during illness or emergencies and allows employees to maximize their salaries by switching roles as needed.

Advice to Management_x: Listen to employee concerns and voice them to higher levels of management. Also, take every opportunity to cross train as many employees as you can. This strengthens the restaurant as a whole, means less empty shifts during illness or emergencies and allows employees to maximize their salaries by switching roles as needed.

Advice to Management_x: Listen to employee concerns and voice them to higher levels of management. Also, take every opportunity to cross train as many employees as you can. This strengthens the restaurant as a whole, means less empty shifts during illness or emergencies and allows employees to maximize their salaries by switching roles as needed.

Title_x: "It was so fun! I would have been a food server forever if it paid more!"

Advice to Management_x: Create a program for employees to work their way up so there is incentive for longevity

Title_x: "Flexible, but all employees are stretched too thin"
Pros_x: Flexible schedule for school, always a plus. It's a very easy job and I've made some great friends.
Cons_x: Employees are asked to do so much that when we get packed no one can keep up including the managers, cooks, QA, togo, servers and sometimes hosts when we are short staffed (to "save labor costs"). We have no bussers so the servers are required to do most of the work for the FOH and they rarely can accomplish keeping a clean restaurant while providing great service to their tables
Advice to Management_x: The idea that Chili's is a "teamwork" environment sounds really fuzzy and warm, but in reality it is just a way to cut labor by making everyone responsible for a little more. This works well on predictable slow days, but when it gets busy, theres a reason why bussers exist. Our GEM scores have significantly decreased due to customers complaining about cleanliness. Also, the host stand is very old school, and because of the paper list system, we hosts lose valuable time. It would be so great to have a hospitality computer management system like at (a similar chain corporate restaurant) Olive Garden so that we could time manage more effectively.

Pros_x: 50% discount on meals for you and a few guests, the more guests you bring in the lower your discount.. Exceptionally well at working with your schedule allowing you the flexibility to do other things.
Cons_x: They prefer to hire management from outside of the organization rather than from within. Not to say they don't promote from within, it's just not as common.. You never know what to expect when coming to work. HQ is always changing things! Half of the time the changes are pretty good but then there is that other half where you scratch your head wondering what they were thinking.. I think they brought in someone from Wal-Mart to run the marketing because they are always "rolling back the prices". The Con to this is that it brings in the bargain shoppers who for some reason or another don't understand the concept of tipping. It is their version of fine dining when they are used to a drive-thru budget.
Advice to Management_x: Build your team up! Promote from within. Don't hide in your office for long periods of time. Lead by example. If you say your going to do something, do it.

Pros_x: Fair tips sometimes, room for small advancement in time (bar tending, trainer, etc.), lots of fun people
Cons_x: Horrible guests, too much pressure from company, too "formatted" and not relaxed enough, management could stand to chill a little (although I'm sure they're just being pressured from a higher power), overall the customers made me hate my job and so I had to quit. White trash and rude, would much rather work at a steakhouse somewhere and make real money.
Advice to Management_x: Chill.

Pros_x: It was fun to be a ChiliHead. The restaurant industry is fast paced, but you learn to work as a team to get things done. You will get an occasionally rude guest but if you enjoy making someone's day better, you will definitely enjoy working at Chili's. Longer than server shifts.
Cons_x: Minimum wage. Rude guests. It is a lot of work to clean a bar. There is a lot of cleaning involved. You will also get sticky.
Advice to Management_x: Have more manager in training opportunities and look for in house talent.

Cons_y: Some late nights. Long shifts. Lots of stress in high volume restaurants.
Advice to Management_y: I was treated very well by all...

Title_x: "An amazing place to work. You become a giant family."
Pros_x: They are amazing at working with outside schedules. I had two jobs for the longest time and they did their best to work with me around that schedule all the time. I've been there a total of 5 years and still love my job (most days).
Cons_x: They switch management around ALOT. We constantly have new management from different stores due to transfers. Chili's is like a family, and people get used to how the work with each other. Each time they introduce a new manager to the team, we have to re-learn what they want, how they want things done and how they want us to work. It's hard and frustrating. Eventually you just stop trying to get along with everyone because they're most likely going to end up gone anyway.
Advice to Management_x: Stop choosing favorites. Everyone can tell who's on your "lists" of people you do and don't like. It shows and it makes it hard to work sometimes. I have personally never had a problem in this area, but some of my coworkers get so frustrated they end up quitting or crying because of the amount of favoritism shown at times. Treat everyone as equals.
Title_y: "One of the best jobs I have ever had."
Pros_y: Great Benefits, quality of life balance +
Cons_y: Some late nights. Long shifts. Lots of stress in high volume restaurants.
Advice to Management_y: I was treated very well by all...

Pros_x: still can make decent money in tips for the time you put into it. like any serving job, the hours are flexable so going to school is easily coordinated around work.
Cons_x: since the economy took the dive down a couple years ago, personalism and being a stand out employee is no longer an asset. too much focus on the bottom line.
Advice to Management_x: your stretching the store managers way too thin. as I see it, they have too much on their plate, and alot of it is stupid micro managing bean counting that doesn't amount to well,"a hill of beans". they aren't able to effectively manage the shifts and people working said shifts. enough already... show a little trust in the ones you have in place to run the stores.

Title_y: "One of the best jobs I have ever had."
Pros_y: Great Benefits, quality of life balance +
Cons_y: Some late nights. Long shifts. Lots of stress in high volume restaurants.
Advice to Management_y: I was treated very well by all...

Title_x: "A good place to work if you don't plan to stay long"
Pros_x: Laid-back atmosphere. HotSchedules implementation allows more flexibility and ease in scheduling/trading shifts. You can make a decent earning if you're put into a good section. The managers work closely with the employees and its conducive to good teamwork.
Cons_x: The biggest con was that the new servers are placed in the smallest and least profitable section. Most lunch shifts, which were about 2-3 hours, I brought home $15-25 in tips which made it hardly worth it to go to work there. It was impossible to support myself. Another con was the fact I had to watch management handle cooked food without gloves or even washing their hands. Absolutely disgusting. I also witnessed the male managers putting their hands on and fondling some of the female servers; they seemed to not be bothered by it but the principle of it disturbed me. Lastly, the favorites game is played **a lot.** The employees who had not befriended or otherwise gained the managers' favor were treated like outsiders and written up for the most trivial offenses.
Advice to Management_x: I would suggest a more thorough selection process for your store managers.

Another con was the fact I had to watch management handle cooked food without gloves or even washing their hands. Absolutely disgusting. I also witnessed the male managers putting their hands on and fondling some of the female servers; they seemed to not be bothered by it but the principle of it disturbed me. Lastly, the favorites game is played **a lot.** The employees who had not befriended or otherwise gained the managers' favor were treated like outsiders and written up for the most trivial offenses.
Advice to Management_x: I would suggest a more thorough selection process for your store managers.

Pros_x: Great discounts on food as long as you're a member of the meal plan. Worked with friendly, happy people. It was right down the street from my house, so I was never late.
Cons_x: Management was rude and frustrating to work with. The incentives for good work were a joke. No reason to go above and beyond the call of service. The food is all terrible for you, as well as being frozen and prepackaged. Not a restaurant but more so fast food with soft-seating and excessive decorations.

Title_x: "Casual atmosphere with heavy emphasis on upselling and sales contests"
Pros_x: A relaxed atmosphere and friendly coworkers make it a generally pleasant place to work at the restaurant level. There is usually an attempt to work with your schedule.
Cons_x: Constant pressure to sell, and upsell, and pressure customers to fill out (long) surveys. Chilis is a casual restaurant, and some of the ambitions of management such as the average amount they expect each customer to spend is simply unrealistic. The constant contests and different-themed sales start to wear on the employees after a while.
Advice to Management_x: Upper management should spend more time at the restaurant level so that they can learn how to form more helpful and realistic policies.

Title_x: "Great if you fit in their box!"
Pros_x: Food, more food, and even more food. Pay is competitive to start with. They solicit feedback. Very diverse workforce.
Cons_x: Don't ever assume that your confidential feedback is actually confidential, it's not, even when it says that it is. Pay structure can change without notice at anytime. No one is currently leading the brand, they say that there is a direction, but that direction changes all the time; making it no direction at all. Pursuit of diversity comes at a cost, sometimes you get the worst fit for the job but they like it because diversity goals are made.
Advice to Management_x: Go back to the basics, stop chasing other concepts, Chili's is not cutting edge, never will be. That's OK, know who you are and be the best at who that is... and for crying out loud, 2 for 20 didn't save you from anything, it just makes the margins thinner.
Title_y: "This is not a job for the lazys..."
Pros_y: there is money to be made (4 bonus' year), lots of support available from other managers and the ability to learn and gain experience
Cons_y: You will work hard, be challenged and learn every aspect of the restaurant...only for the lazys is this a con
Advice to Management_y: You have to have pride and passion for what you do. The best thing you can do for your guest is MAKE THEM FEEL SPECIAL. OH, and it's cool to be a "Chilihead". :)

Cons_x: You will work hard, be challenged and learn every aspect of the restaurant...only for the lazys is this a con
Advice to Management_x: You have to have pride and passion for what you do. The best thing you can do for your guest is MAKE THEM FEEL SPECIAL. OH, and it's cool to be a "Chilihead". :)

Pros_x: free food, discounted food when coming in
Cons_x: The managers where horrible, the store manager is a joke. she shouldn't even have a job, let alone over a store. Girls there where so petty. All I ever did was get yelled at.. Advice to Management_x: listen to your workers when they complain about their store manager 24/7

Title_x: "Great Company to grow in the Hospitality Industry"
Pros_x: If you have the drive you can work your way from waiter to GM. Every restaurant is different, so how much you like it will depend on the GM and managers.
Cons_x: Waiters:Train on how be better at up selling and other sales tricks.. Managers:Make sure you hire the right ones, to often they are in the back and not helping out during the busy time.
Title_y: "Great Company to grow in the Hospitality Industry"
Pros_y: If you have the drive you can work your way from waiter to GM. Every restaurant is different, so how much you like it will depend on the GM and managers.
Cons_y: Waiters:Train on how be better at up selling and other sales tricks.. Managers:Make sure you hire the right ones, to often they are in the back and not helping out during the busy time.

Title_x: "Overwhelming, not quality of life. All the responsibility is yours, GM is never in the building."
Pros_x: Good Benefits + bonus + 401k after 1 year. Free food and 50% off in other restaurant with the same company.
Cons_x: Gm's and Area directors are very unprofessional. They show Favoritism for some other people even they are very bad employes.
Advice to Management_x: Managers hast to do everything, cook, clean, food running, dish washing to keep labor in track.

Title_x: "Chili's is one of my absolute favorite jobs!"
Pros_x: Great co-workers, fast paced environment, fast money, get to meet all types of people!, great food and management.
Cons_x: can get stressful when it's busy, but the money makes it worth it!
Advice to Management_x: Give the managers at the Chili's in Stowe a raise, we have the most incredible management any employee could ask for. I have absolutely no complaints, and would highly recommend employment at our location.

Title_x: "Long term employee that has been in many different positions"
Pros_x: It is a fun company to work for and they always have contests and stuff to give away. I have never had a problem with any managers and I always have great flexbility with my schedule. They also have a Brinker family fund in case you have a family emergency and they will help pay bills and rent.
Cons_x: The company has recently taken away vacation pay for hourly team members though they do give money for how many years you have worked for them. Also the insurance is horrible for part time and full time.
Advice to Management_x: Remember that alot of employees are working there while going to school so when they need to change their schedules they are not doing it to be difficult.

Advice to Management_y: Managers hast to do everything, cook, clean, food running, dish washing to keep labor in track.

Title_x: "Long term employee that has been in many different positions"
Pros_x: It is a fun company to work for and they always have contests and stuff to give away. I have never had a problem with any managers and I always have great flexbility with my schedule. They also have a Brinker family fund in case you have a family emergency and they will help pay bills and rent.
Cons_x: The company has recently taken away vacation pay for hourly team members though they do give money for how many years you have worked for them. Also the insurance is horrible for part time and full time.
Advice to Management_x: Remember that alot of employees are working there while going to school so when they need to change their schedules they are not doing it to be difficult.
Title_y: "Overwhelming, not quality of life. All the responsibility is yours, GM is never in the building."

Pros_x: tends to be a high volume restaurant, so quantity of customers should help make for high sales. affordable food. well-known
Cons_x: like staff, management is a revolving door. Extremely high turn-over rate. customers tend to flood in for the 2-20 deal... higher volume... lower check averages
Advice to Management_x: realize your hardworking employees hold significant value to your success

Pros_x: People are nice, and management can be ok. Hours are pretty good if you can convince them to let you work certain hours.
Cons_x: Servers treat people terribly. Not just other co-workers in the restaurant but also people they are serving. People come in to work and leave within 3 months. Even when I was there for 4 months, 10 people had come and gone. Hostess are real jerks, only care about themselves.
Advice to Management_x: Do better interview process to get a sense of the real person.

Title_x: "Great people and benefits for team members"
Pros_x: Great people and culture. Very organized company with updated systems in place. Good home office support. Great place for a new manager to learn the ropes of restaurant managment. Great training program.
Cons_x: Bonus plan changed and became not very obtainable. Took individuality out of manager decision making to do what is right for individual restaurant.
Advice to Management_x: Give power back to MP and GM of restaurant to do what is best for individual restaurant. Stop hiring upper levels from outside of company to keep the culture alive.

Title_x: "Not somewhere you want to work as a manager"
Pros_x: Has name recognition due to popularity and success in other markets.
Cons_x: Take it from the spouse of a former manager at this location, there is no teamwork or development mentality. It's all about catching you doing something wrong but not telling you how to properly handle that scenario in the future. The management team is so busy trying to throw each other under the bus and make themselves look good individually that there is no room for teamwork nor is there any encouragement to develop team work. Managers at the GM and RM level do not practice what they preach by following the Chilis standard but will certainly reprimand anyone umder them not following the standards.
Advice to Management_x: Someone from Chilis Corp needs to plant a manager spy to witness the lack of leadership and development that is occuring in the Nebraska Chilis Management team.

The management team is so busy trying to throw each other under the bus and make themselves look good individually that there is no room for teamwork nor is there any encouragement to develop team work. Managers at the GM and RM level do not practice what they preach by following the Chilis standard but will certainly reprimand anyone umder them not following the standards.
Advice to Management_x: Someone from Chilis Corp needs to plant a manager spy to witness the lack of leadership and development that is occuring in the Nebraska Chilis Management team.

Pros_x: regulars and the staff , I at least moved up enough for self learning purposes but it took way too long, closes around 10, safe area
Cons_x: worst area to work, people regularly dip out on the tab, it was a franchise before but then was bought by corporate....we didn't know if we would even have a job for a year since they werent sure about buying the store
Advice to Management_x: Pay attention to the servers themselves not the surveys. You have amazing employees there that dont get moved up to the positions they deserve and you get stuck with terrible employees that steal from you , too few employees due to this I almost passed out on fourth of july one year because we didnt have enough servers so i didnt get a day off for 2 months every day i had off i was called in -_-, i quit because i found a better job, but honestly even when corporate took over I was done with the place, tho I have heard good things about every other restaurant

Pros_x: The best part of the company is the atmosphere. I worked at a Utah location all the way through college - it was a great way to make extra money and get the social interaction that double-majoring didn't allow. Chili's makes a community of its employees. Right before I started, a host/bus staff member (a friend of a friend of mine and a brother of two other employees) passed away, and Chili's paid for his funeral and offered emotional support to all of the mourning employees. Great company.
Cons_x: Because it is casual dining, occasionally you have to work with people who don't take any pride in their work and that can be frustrating. Also a little cult-y, but not terribly so. As a trainer, I indoctrinated new employees in a way that sometimes felt cheesy, but it really was like a family.
Advice to Management_x: Keep on keepin' on.

Title_x: "Great part time job for college students, busiest restaurant in town."
Pros_x: Very busy, excellent GM with great AM's. Flexible scheduling due to high volume of employees. BOH does a nice job.
Cons_x: Not a great crowd who comes in late to eat, long hours with little breaks on doubles, picky managers about little things, and many employees have had personal items stolen from the BOH. (sunglasses, wallets, cash out of books, ect.)
Advice to Management_x: Implement surveillance cameras for reported theft, hire quicker more experienced bartenders, close earlier on Friday/Saturday nights. Waste of labor hours when less than 200 dollars in sales is generated in the last hour and a half.

The management team is so busy trying to throw each other under the bus and make themselves look good individually that there is no room for teamwork nor is there any encouragement to develop team work. Managers at the GM and RM level do not practice what they preach by following the Chilis standard but will certainly reprimand anyone umder them not following the standards.
Advice to Management_y: Someone from Chilis Corp needs to plant a manager spy to witness the lack of leadership and development that is occuring in the Nebraska Chilis Management team.

Pros_x: Larger table sections than any other restaurant, committed to making everyone money, greater starter place for restaurant business, ability to move around with in store.
Cons_x: Constant flow of people including managers, everyone is disposable, ticket times are long and thus stress is high,

Pros_x: Having some nice customers who don't make you want to tear your hair out.
Cons_x: Badly trained because apparently the managers don't know what they're doing.
Advice to Management_x: Learn to train your hostesses better. Each manager told me something different about how to seat sections, and when one would tell me one thing, the other would say I was doing it all wrong. This cause drama between servers and I because I apparently wasn't "doing my job right" according to them. Most likely considering 3 different managers told me 3 different things on a daily basis. Get your "stuff" (I'll be friendly there) together.

Title_x: "Okay work while you're in college, but don't get stuck here!"
Pros_x: The social atmosphere--if you're single and/or don't have any children. Working with the same people day in and day out can foster some great friendships. Depending your area, good tips. Also, good opportunity to travel around, as you can transfer from one Chilis to another. I started in Tampa, FL, moved to Houston, TX, went to Pensacola, FL, then to Colorado Springs, CO.
Cons_x: Management is ridiculous. Instead of firing people, they will just hire more people on and cut hours so that people are forced to go elsewhere. Also, they wait until the last minute to post the schedule. New schedules start Thursday; you can expect to know what you're working on Wednesday, usually. They do NOT promote from within, so don't believe that BS.
Advice to Management_x: Promote from within and post schedules further in advance--people have kids and have to arrange childcare!

The management team is so busy trying to throw each other under the bus and make themselves look good individually that there is no room for teamwork nor is there any encouragement to develop team work. Managers at the GM and RM level do not practice what they preach by following the Chilis standard but will certainly reprimand anyone umder them not following the standards.
Advice to Management_y: Someone from Chilis Corp needs to plant a manager spy to witness the lack of leadership and development that is occuring in the Nebraska Chilis Management team.

Title_x: "Good Place to work to get by"
Pros_x: Great staff to work with. Morning Staff is usually the older crowd that have families so usually the morning crew are great with team work. But you tend to make more money at night. If you are a food server or bar tender you bring home your tips the same day. They offer 401k and match a certain percent after 1 year of working at Chili's . When you become a a trainer you get 50 percent off the meals at all of the Chili's on the island except the Waikiki location.
Cons_x: If you want to attain health care from this company it's hard to attain. You have to sacrifice, be flexible, and work harder than the rest to get health care. Food servers make a quarter less than minimum wage.

Pros_x: Great Co-workers and dedicated staff.. Promote from with-in. I love serving our guests and the community
Cons_x: SLOW to promote beyond the Asst. Manager level. Pay is just barely enough to be competitive with industry, but anyone with ambition would not likely stay. Work/ life balance is horrible, but that comes with the territory in restaurants
Advice to Management_x: Great corporate culture, very talented mangers in your Maryland Market. Please stop pushing the Productivity and Labor goals so hard down everyone's throat. We understand profits are important in a business, but this Brand is very profitable as it is. At some point we need to stop worrying about the share holders best interest and start concentrating on the well being of our work force and their moral. Not to mention in the constant effort to always save on labor costs the guests are the #1 victim! They and we deserve better.

At some point we need to stop worrying about the share holders best interest and start concentrating on the well being of our work force and their moral. Not to mention in the constant effort to always save on labor costs the guests are the #1 victim! They and we deserve better.

Pros_x: 50% discount on food (not including alchohol)
Cons_x: -Get treated unfairly. - Got food poisoning twice after eating there. - Unorganized management. - Have to pay for all your uniforms. - Have to pay for an Application on the phone that is the way they schedule you, etc.. - Food takes over 45 minutes to come out on average, so you deal with a lot a lot a lot of angry guests.
Advice to Management_x: -Fire the managers that dont know how to interact with servers. You need people to support you at your job not fight you on it.. -Hire new cooks that dont disappear during a lunch rush. -Follow through with discipline on people instead of trying to be everyone's favorite manager

Pros_x: corporate will back you up in a pinch, our store was esp great during the hurricane..met wonderful people. 50% discount at sister restaurants
Cons_x: its really hard to give great service, via 'team service' or otherwise when our bussers are taken away..we have 8-12 tables between 2 servers we have to bus EVERYTHING ourselves, run food all while getting double sat (God forbid someone needs an allergy menu, or takes forever to order, then we're really backed up) and the menu is all over the place
Pros_y: Bonus structure is rewarding. Opportunity for advancement.
Cons_y: Healthcare benefits are not that great.
Advice to Management_y: Offer better healthcare benefits. Deductibles are way too high.

Title_x: "5 years in t g i fridays kingdom"
Pros_x: work in chills. Working as a supervisor with a salary of at least 4000sr
Cons_x: To lead the team on each shift and ensure the company service standards are upheld.. • Escort customers to their tables.. • Explain how various menu items are prepared, describing ingredients and cooking methods.. • Present menus to customers and answer questions about dishes and make recommendations.. • Remove dishes and glasses from tables or counters, and take them to kitchen for cleaning.. • Serve food and/or beverages to customers; prepare and serve specialty dishes at tables.. • Check customers are enjoying their meals and take action to correct any problems.. • Work closely with other team members to ensure excellent service is provided to all customers.. • Take directions and guidance from managers.. • Check customers’ identification in order to ensure that they meet minimum age requirements for. consumption of alcoholic beverages.. • Prepare checks that itemise and total meal costs using the Micros Point of Sales system
Advice to Management_x: Leadership-Communication-Budgeting. Shift leaders are often be charged with monitoring stock levels and placing orders with suppliers for the replenishment of ingredients and drinks. They must be able to source quality ingredients at low prices and ensure they don't over-order. Any ingredients that have to be trashed at the end of the day can seriously eat into a restaurant's margins.
Pros_y: Bonus structure is rewarding. Opportunity for advancement.
Cons_y: Healthcare benefits are not that great.
Advice to Management_y: Offer better healthcare benefits. Deductibles are way too high.

Pros_x: I can' think of one positive thing that came out of working at Chili's.
Cons_x: Lazy cooks, No Teamwork, Managers didn't even know how to cook or make meals, Work week started on Thursdays and the schedule would come out early Thursday Morning (4am). After working there I will no longer eat at a Chili's restaurant nor a Brinker owned restaurant.
Advice to Management_x: Ugh be a real manager? We must have had 7 different managers and when I quit I was still unsure who was at what level. Work on Teamwork, when you only have 2 or 3 cooks working on a Wednesday or Thursday night and you have 2 of the cooks running one station and the other cook is running 3 its quite unfair.

Title_x: "Great place to work if you want zero responsibility."
Pros_x: -Schedules tend to be extremely flexible.. -The company holds an annual monthly donation drive for St. Jude's Children's Hospital, and 100% of the donations go directly to those in need.. -Friendly Staff and Management
Cons_x: -There's absolutely no accountability at any level.. -Lack of communication between management leads to inadequate staffing and food orders. -Gratuity for large parties is only suggested and not required.. -In an effort to reduce the cost of labor, stores operate on the bare minimum. Servers are expected to bus, run, qa, host, dish wash, clean, and assist with Togo orders all while they serve their tables.

Title_x: "Don't work here unless you are desperate"
Pros_x: -Get to know people. -Learn the restaurant business
Cons_x: The management was never on the same page. I would always ask them what goes in what, and would get 4 different answers. Also, I did WAY too much running around, dealing with wrong orders etc. for the minimum wage salary I received. Also had to deal with lazy servers, and I did to go so I ended up tending to a lot of the tables' needs. The servers would be over in a corner talking! To go was a very fast paced environment and since you're on your own you REALLY have to know what side items go with what dish, etc.

Title_x: "Fun coworkers, but extremely corporate and lacking in respect for employees"
Pros_x: -fun coworkers. -50% off at all Brinker-owned restaurants. -facilitates an annual fundraiser for St. Jude Children's Research Hospital. -decent tips. -fairly flexible (Though this depends on the manager. Some respect our lives outside of work more than others.)
Cons_x: -Corporate is more concerned about the bottom line than about its employees. They got rid of our bussers, cut our hours, and make cooks pull double duty as cook and dishwasher simultaneously, all for the sake of "helping us make more money" (which thus far has been questionable).. -Extremely corporate! We have no freedom to be ourselves, though the higher management will do everything in their power to make us believe otherwise. (We are constantly secret shopped, written up if we do not meet unreasonable guidelines, etc.). -We have had problems with managers who seem to be incompetent. Several of the managers I have worked with do not have even basic cooking skills and are very unfamiliar with our menu and our computer system.. -The company is always more concerned with keeping customers than with having any respect for the employees or the company itself. Problems are always remedied with free food and coupons, even if the customer is obviously at fault.. -The health insurance offered is so bad that even my general manager advised me to purchase outside insurance.
Advice to Management_x: Respect the opinions of your staff- we are the face of the restaurant and are more aware of customer desires than the corporate staff who have never encountered a customer.
Pros_y: Bonus structure is rewarding. Opportunity for advancement.
Cons_y: Healthcare benefits are not that great.
Advice to Management_y: Offer better healthcare benefits. Deductibles are way too high.

Pros_x: Met some new friends, nothing else.
Cons_x: Horrible management. Too much work hours/responsibilities for a host, for the poor pay. Get blamed for things that happen that have nothing to do with you. Customers getting in your face and complaining, and even blaming you for things they don't like 98% of each shift. Would not recommend. Not a happy environment for myself and customers always seemed upset. Left after 3 weeks.
Advice to Management_x: Get your priorities together. Stop losing schedules of when people can and cannot work.

Cons_y: Healthcare benefits are not that great.

Pros_x: Allow me to dig deep to find some sort of positive feedback on such a negative facility. .. *Good Pay. Host: 8.75$. ToGo: 8.00$ +tips. . *Fun Environment. It is fun purely because of your coworkers!! Laid back, calm and cool people.. . *Free Food:. It Works like this: On a average shift, you must pay for your food. It will be half off, granted you're selecting from the TM Shift Meal Menu.. To obtain free food, you MUST be working a double. Even then, your food options are limited to the TM Shift Meal Menu.. . *Tattoo and Piercings. Just don't over do it.
Cons_x: -rubs hands together- Let's Do This.. . *Favoritism:. Managers calculate your hours based off of if they like you or not.. Managers give you days off based off of if they like you or not.. Managers cut (allow you to go home) based off of if they like you or not.. . *Senior Workers:. Let's say you have your To Goschedule and you know you are due to be cut at 9:00pm and therefore made plans. Let's say a Host who picked up a shift (meaning they took that specific work hours by choice) but decided she wanted to go home at 9.. Quick as lightning you're suddenly hosting and stuck until closing (12 midnight) and that Senior worker is going home at 9. But those tables can't turn, you'd better not ask to switch shifts last second!!. . It's Just WRONG. * Let's say a nice Host retrieved a lost cellphone and returned it to the male who lost it. Let's say they tip you a dollar. The manager will tear it in half, pocket it and walk away.. . Second Job?. *Let's say you get a second job. Chilis will immediately terminate your hours. If they can't have 100% of you, they don't want you.. Just don't work here.. . Chilis. off of 59. Directly across from Deerbrook Mall
Advice to Management_x: You Don't Have The Right To Talk Badly To Us "because you're a manager"
Pros_y: Bonus structure is rewarding. Opportunity for advancement.
Cons_y: Healthcare benefits are not that great.
Advice to Management_y: Offer better healthcare benefits. Deductibles are way too high.

Pros_x: There is a great variety of people that come in. When training as a server, you are given full meals to eat to experience the food. Management does an awesome job with selecting workers. Everyone is very fun and sociable as well as helpful.
Cons_x: Managers play favorites so they give better table sections to the people they like. The hosts also play favorites and seat more customers in certain people's sections more than others. The mangers are also very unprofessional. Chili's doesn't drug test s often the cooks would come in high.
Advice to Management_x: Hire better managers.

Pros_x: Working at Chili's you'll meet great people (both your coworkers and the guests), have a flexible work schedule, there's consistent food and drink quality, high table turnover with large sections, a focus on team work, a fast paced work day that's never boring and there's always a contest going on you can win extra bonuses in.
Cons_x: If you're full time, the health benefits are dismal- whether you are hourly or in management. $6000 deductible on your health insurance for single folks, $12,000 for a family. $750 emergency room copay that doesn't even cover all the ER bills. Full time hourly team members had their vacation time taken away in lieu of an annual bonus, that is significantly less than vacation time adds up to..  The company is always looking to do more with less- cutting labor hours often at the expense of the team running smoothly. Final straw for me was when the decision was made to make the bar area into a "sports bar like atmosphere"- with only attractive young people behind the bar. When at a meeting the girls were told to wear more makeup and tighter shirts, I knew it was time to move on.
Advice to Management_x: To upper management, actually, as usually when a in store manager makes a poor decision it's because he or she is trying to make numbers or keep their job- go back to putting the guests first. A meat market bar isn't going to win you the casual dining segment- great service, great food and customer experiences is. If you invest a little more in your team, you'll find they've got your back and will again be proud of the company they work for.
Pros_y: Bonus structure is rewarding. Opportunity for advancement.
Cons_y: Healthcare benefits are not that great.
Advice to Management_y: Offer better healthcare benefits. Deductibles are way too high.

If you invest a little more in your team, you'll find they've got your back and will again be proud of the company they work for.
Pros_y: Bonus structure is rewarding. Opportunity for advancement.
Cons_y: Healthcare benefits are not that great.
Advice to Management_y: Offer better healthcare benefits. Deductibles are way too high.

Pros_x: It's a Job, There is really nothing positive to say about this train wreck

Just about everyone is rude and lazy and expects everyone else to pick up their slack. Advice to Management_x: Just Quit so this blight of a company goes under already

Title_x: "I loved the people I worked with and the company was great."

Cons_x: As with any waitressing, the tips could be bad. We tended to be slightly overstaffed most of the time. I also wish they had a food runner or two.

Title_x: "An interesting expeirence.. good way to earn quick money"
Pros_x: Working at Chili's was a quick way to earn money. Your salary even though low covers your taxes so you get to walk out with cash every night and keep exactly what you earn. Hours are flexible around your schedule.
Cons_x: Management can be annoying. Very short-sighted and often do not really care about your needs.
Advice to Management_x: Managers need to be more concerned with the well-being of their workers.

Title_x: "Chili's is more than just a job, you get to make a difference with St. Jude's: truely phenomenal!""

Cons_x: Management sometimes sounds scripted. Corporate trains them to answer each scenario with a script.
Advice to Management_x: Remember that the employees are PEOPLE. Keep it real, knock of the "corporate says to answer this question this-a-way" bs- we can see right through that. Remember to be compassionate.

Pros_x: This restaurant provided a fun atmosphere and was very good about working with my schedule. The management team was approachable and understanding.
Cons_x: Compensation in my opinion is poor. Mandatory "tip outs" to bartenders and busers was unfair, especially when it was calculated from percentage of sales.
Pros_y: Work conditions, product, flexibility in schedule
Cons_y: Development potential, lots of unnecessary change

Title_x: "Former dishwasher West Valley Utah 3403 decker lake drive the management are rude behind a face of a smile."
Pros_x: loved the team members very nice waitresses
Cons_x: The Management Talks crap behind your back they expect you to improve quickly when it takes time to improve they push and expect to learn quickly they fire people who try. plus the sprayer messes up your wrist .
Advice to Management_x: you guys need to realize it takes time to improve on a job task and understand theres some people that have learning disabilities so quit pushing people to do crap and help a team member to develop and quit being panzees trying to call people to fire em. learn to do confrontation and quit putting your lives to get your egos drunk. cause thats all the managers care about.
Pros_y: Work conditions, product, flexibility in schedule
Cons_y: Development potential, lots of unnecessary change

Pros_x: Easy money, some days I've walked out with over 200 in a 4 hr. shift. Never a day where I left with less than minimum wage.
Cons_x: Inconsistent, might have one day making 200 then the next you only make 30. Shifts are not guaranteed, and there is a lot of drama between staff. They do not pay attention to employees availability or requested days off.
Advice to Management_x: Listen to staff more
Title_y: "Loyalty not rewarded... must read before working for Chili's"
Pros_y: Brinker family fund helps out when a tragedy happens.
Cons_y: WorkWorked for the company almost 10 years. 5 as a server and 4 as a manager. When I got married I decided that I wanted to be a better husband and father. I asked to be demoted and turned in my demotion letter. After my time was up I was terminated for not producing well as a manager. I was singled out by the CEO, RD and AD multiple times
Advice to Management_y: I have no words..... just completely disappointed that my 10 years was so easily forgotten.

Advice to Management_x: Focus on quality over speed.

Advice to Management_y: I have no words..... just completely disappointed that my 10 years was so easily forgotten.

Pros_x: Good money on weekends. Generally all of the food is good. The fellow TMs are usually fun and when MGT allows, can have a great time.
Cons_x: Too much back work, MGT takes advantage of servers low hourly rate. Unreachable goals such as sales/hr, guests/hr, and earnings/hr. Unreachable because of the amount of extra hours that is spent doing back work and rolling silverware is sometimes just as long (or longer) than the time spent actually serving tables. MGT plays favorites and gives better shifts to favorites. MGT stresses GEM comments and good numbers to obtain good shifts, but does not follow through. Dirty plates/cups/silverware. MGT not helpful in fixing problems.
Advice to Management_x: Servers are the face of the restaurant, don't overwork them where they don't enjoy working there.

Pros_x: Room to grow professionally if you show interest, good core values and culture. Wonderful training program if you are willing to learn and apply yourself. Pretty consistent shifts. Loved the recent remodel and transition to ALOHA POS. A lot of employee outings every year, like the "Chili's Trainer Olympics" and the rafting trip. Loved being able to work with St. Jude every year. Constantly have margarita contests and it's nice to have a little friendly competition between co-workers and all of the other restaurants in the brand.
Cons_x: A LOT of coupons and money-saving deals. Although it brings in guests who would not normally come in, it hurts the income for servers and bartenders. Worry too much about labor costs. No bussers and hosts aren't always available, especially during the lunch shifts. Servers and bartenders are responsible for greeting guests at the door during the daytime and can sometimes get overwhelming if it's busy.
Pros_y: Making changes to become the best in their segment of the industry
Cons_y: Lots of micro management on business plans and rules
Advice to Management_y: Become a partner with your GMP's

Pros_x: Well Run, professional, respectable starting wage, easy room for advancement.
Cons_x: Inherent heirarchy, many workers (station trainers included) speak next to no english. No lienecy given even in training (particularly for cooks). Speed is favored over efficiency. Continuous pressure to prepare meals ASAP.
Advice to Management_x: Overall Chili's is run efficiently. However in terms of training in other more technical positions more specificity is needed. Managements perspective was that repetition with trainers would correct all errors. But if making a dozen different dishes nightly knowing the exact portions would be key.
Pros_y: Making changes to become the best in their segment of the industry
Cons_y: Lots of micro management on business plans and rules
Advice to Management_y: Become a partner with your GMP's

Cons_x: Under staffing has become the goal in saving money

Pros_x: compensation, extra day off for birthday an anniversary
Cons_x: Managers are used to prep, do dishes, cook, QA...not coach or lead others. 60-70 hour work weeks with little-no weekend days off. Non-existent Quality of Life. Blurry future as upper management is not clear on rollouts or communications. Constant last-minute changes to budget plans, making it hard to hit your bonus
Advice to Management_x: You can keep changing plans, you can keep coming at us with new goals like BRGs (which DON'T pay the bills), but someone is still going to have to prep and it is always the manager. During my 60 hour work weeks, I spend 90% of that cooking or prepping and I'm not the only manager in my area that deals with this frustration. You brag about hiring talented leaders...use them to LEAD and coach. We are stuck in function ALL day.. . There are also some locations that are still making lots of money for the company (mine) and we are still getting yelled at for BRGs and guest satisfaction scores. If a location is up double digits and beating their labor percentage...realize that THESE factors affect the bottom line...and thank me for your inflated bonuses.. . Our culture used to be what stood us apart...that is no longer true. We haven't heard anything/preached anything in 2 years.. . Start promoting the managers you say you will, follow through on promises, get the prep tool fixed (always a bug) and realize that MenuLink is not a cure-all.
Pros_y: Making changes to become the best in their segment of the industry
Cons_y: Lots of micro management on business plans and rules
Advice to Management_y: Become a partner with your GMP's

Pros_x: compensation, extra day off for birthday an anniversary
Cons_x: Managers are used to prep, do dishes, cook, QA...not coach or lead others. 60-70 hour work weeks with little-no weekend days off. Non-existent Quality of Life. Blurry future as upper management is not clear on rollouts or communications. Constant last-minute changes to budget plans, making it hard to hit your bonus
Advice to Management_x: You can keep changing plans, you can keep coming at us with new goals like BRGs (which DON'T pay the bills), but someone is still going to have to prep and it is always the manager. During my 60 hour work weeks, I spend 90% of that cooking or prepping and I'm not the only manager in my area that deals with this frustration. You brag about hiring talented leaders...use them to LEAD and coach. We are stuck in function ALL day.. . There are also some locations that are still making lots of money for the company (mine) and we are still getting yelled at for BRGs and guest satisfaction scores. If a location is up double digits and beating their labor percentage...realize that THESE factors affect the bottom line...and thank me for your inflated bonuses.. . Our culture used to be what stood us apart...that is no longer true. We haven't heard anything/preached anything in 2 years.. . Start promoting the managers you say you will, follow through on promises, get the prep tool fixed (always a bug) and realize that MenuLink is not a cure-all.

Title_x: "A great place to work if you like to be micromanaged."
Pros_x: With being such a large company, they have nice benefits. Another benefit of having numerous locations would be the ease of transferring if need be. They do a great deal of promoting from within, which is great.
Cons_x: Lack of culture and work/life balance. Micromanaging to an extreme.
Advice to Management_x: In my 4 years there as a manager. we had 3 different Area Directors. There is always a reason for turnover, if you want to see it. I always felt that suggestions for improvement fell on deaf ears. Though promoting managers from within is great, it really limits any possible positive ideas from other concepts due to them not having any. Maybe, instead of hiring or promoting managers that need to be micromanaged Brinker should spend some energy hiring managers that can think and act for themselves.

Though promoting managers from within is great, it really limits any possible positive ideas from other concepts due to them not having any. Maybe, instead of hiring or promoting managers that need to be micromanaged Brinker should spend some energy hiring managers that can think and act for themselves.

Title_x: "A great place to work if you like to be micromanaged."

Cons_x: Lack of culture and work/life balance. Micromanaging to an extreme.

Advice to Management_x: Many of you need to take responsibility for your actions and stop putting all the work and blame on the employees. Title_x: "Fun, fast paced work environment, with late hours."
Pros_x: Chili's does an excelent job training managers. They give you all the tools you need for success.
Cons_x: As a new manager to a very tenured management team, the hours I recieved were always late night hours.
Advice to Management_x: Place new managers in a team that will be open to haveing someone new, not with long time team members that have no desire to help teach or guide new managers.

Title_x: "easy hire - bad mgmt and scheduling - selfish co-workers"
Pros_x: easy entry level job with different options, fast to learn, moderate to good food, flexible work schedules, semi friendly co-workers,
Cons_x: management is unapproachable and avoids you, conflicting and contradicting information on how to get your concerns and requests for help heard.. Let go without actually being told!!!!. . I was hired with little history of working in the restaurant industry. As it was my first job with a chain restaurant they said I will be trained and start off with the To-Go phone in and take out conunter to learn the register and menu items.. . The interview contained a lot about how working there is like family but it turns out that this family is using and cheating on one another.. My trainers I worked alongside for the entire shifts did either not share the tip jar with me or only gave me less then a 1/4 of what we both accumulated. So much about equal sharing for equal work.. . After training period was over the different on duty managers as well as franchise owner and scheduling manager told me different ways on how to communicate my availability in order to be scheduled for regular shifts.. I ended up not being scheduled for literally weeks as I followed anyones rules on how to make that clear when I could work but it seemed that none was the right way.. When I stopped by in the almost empty restuarants during the day here and there I was just shoved out of the way by management on duty - had no time to talk.. . I finally got the whole run down by scheduling manager and called her as requested before a deadline just to be not scheduled again.. . The final straw was that I was NOT told that I was let go - but rather when I signed in to the online scheduling request website my profile was gone When I tried using their corp. website to look up my previous paystubs my user ID was no longer recognized period.. Guess that's their way to tell people you're out???
Advice to Management_x: don't tell staff you have open door policy but then ignore them when they need you

Pros_x: There is an answer for everything and any situation you might encounter, so you don't have to worry about disappointing a customer in that regard. It is also nice that they run a "partner system" within the sections, so ideally at least one person is always there to help you. I was also fortunate to have managers that seemed to care about their employees and doing whatever they could in their power to make sure that everyone felt comfortable.
Cons_x: Because the company is so large, it doesn't give the server much room to be their own person. At times it felt very scripted and unnatural. The amount of selling you have to do with the customers can also be a bit uncomfortable. At times it felt like the servers were pushing options that were not wanted on the people who were dining.

Cons_y: structure is a little lacking.

Title_x: "Great Job, Great Team, and Lots of Flexibility!"
Pros_x: -Lots of great team members... they become like family. -Great management-- most have moved up through the ranks. -Flexible scheduling for students. -Servers can make money on the fly
Cons_x: -Like any job based on tips/commission, you aren't guaranteed a set amount. -Depending on your location, it can be hard to make decent money during lunch, unless you are a closer. Closers are typically staffed based on seniority, though newbies can switch shifts at times. -This isn't really a con, but to some it may be. Brinker concepts (like Chili's) went away from charging Gratuity to large parties years ago. Customers can take advantage of this... but servers did to, hence the change in policy.
Advice to Management_x: Remember your roots! ...and keep doing what you're doing.
Pros_y: Fun environment and great team work
Cons_y: structure is a little lacking.
Advice to Management_y: create more structure throughout the brand.

Pros_x: Salary, co workers, fun work environment. Lots of opportunity for advancement if willing to relocate. Industry leading kitchen equipment. Lots of great ideas, but lacking in the implementation
Cons_x: Absolutely horrendous work/life balance. They expect you to live there 24/7.. Bonus structure has changed and it's almost impossible to bonus well anymore, even though your restaurant is making the company money.. Restaurant managers get the short end of the stick. Company is all about the hourly team members quality of life and work experience but doesn't seem to care about the managers.. Constant changes with many if them contradicting themselves over and over. Absolutely terrible benefits. Almost not even worth having the health insurance with the unbelievable deductibles. Too much emphasis on the MEE (My Employee Engagement) surveys. Even high po managers are in danger of losing their jobs over them even though there is no way to even control wether or not there is not cheating done on them. My Area Director was crazy. He showed favoritism. Went psycho crazy when our Regional Director would do his random announced visits which ended up being total dog and pony shows. Crazy budgets and goals to hit which are made by pencil pushers sitting at a desk only worried about pleasing the investors. As in any job, sometimes there is crazy back stabbing just to get ahead
Advice to Management_x: Quit screwing over your Restaurant Managers. If you are going to terminate managers over MEE Surveys, then put more security in place so they are more accurate. There is cheating both ways on these surveys. Disgruntled team members filling out multiples and unethical managers filling out multiple positive ones. Try to not contradict yourselves with the massive amounts of changes. Offer better health insurance and benefits. Change the bonus structure. Take it easy on the budgets and goals that are needed to succeed. Many goals are close to impossible to hit which is requiring the managers to be labor savers and not properly lead and also the restaurants not being staffed properly which is leading to poor guest service and restaurants not being cleaned properly. Many of your restaurants are profiting and making the company money, yet the managers are still not bonusing.
Pros_y: Fun environment and great team work
Cons_y: structure is a little lacking.
Advice to Management_y: create more structure throughout the brand.

Pros_x: Set in stone preparation procedures and recipes, never short on equipment, great people. The training materials are great and thorough, you will never be bored working for this company, and you can work any station you want and transfer to any store you want if approved by management.
Cons_x: Hours aren't always great unless you like working nights, labor management is intense, volume of select stores can get insane often without enough employees to handle it. The company was on a wage freeze while I was employed, so as one of the better employees I didn't have much incentive to stay or keep performing at my best because I made the same as everyone else regardless of how they performed.
Advice to Management_x: Loosen labor restrictions placed on kitchen managers to allow adequate scheduling. And reward good employees with a raise.
Pros_y: Fun environment and great team work
Cons_y: structure is a little lacking.
Advice to Management_y: create more structure throughout the brand.

Pros_x: Great serving staff made it fun to work, and the other hosts were fun when on duty at the same time. No one can ever say they didn't give me enough hours...
Cons_x: I had requested a few days off, so they decided that the days I worked, I was going to work from 9 in the morning until 12 at night. The doors closed at 11, so I never really understood the point of keeping me until 12 when I had already done my cleaning during the slow, later hours. Also, on two of those 9 am-12 am days, they took my two hour lunch break away for various reasons. I'm pretty sure that's not even legal. Management turned over faster than the waitstaff.
Advice to Management_x: Don't insist on hiring only 3 hosts when there always had to be 1 in the restaraunt on normal hours and 2 on Friday and Saturday nights. It just doesn't make sense and we were horribly overworked. I signed up for a part-time job, not 40 hours/week plus overtime. Also, I actually made more at Chick-fil-a. They paid $.25 over minimum wage.
Pros_y: Fun environment and great team work

Title_x: "Coworkers are great, but the customers can really bring you down."
Pros_x: -Great coworkers. -Build friendships with coworkers. -Decent amount of money being made if you're a server. -Everyone that works here makes it feel like a family. -50% discount on days you work and 25% on days you don't
Cons_x: -Customers can be very rude. -You start to feel like a punching bag for everyone. -Sometimes you feel like you give way more than you receive. -Old manager only ever told us what we were doing wrong, and never acknowledged what we did right. -Lunch shifts you may walk out with $8 dollars for two hours. (Varies)
Advice to Management_x: Don't just acknowledge what we do wrong, but show that we are doing things right and well also. This would definitely make me want to work harder.

Advice to Management_x: don't talk down to long term quality employees, up starting wages to stop getting fast food rejects, quit accepting and even encouraging mediocrity.

Title_x: "Good way to make quick money, not good in the long run"
Pros_x: Brinker International (the company that owns Chili's) has an excellent corporate structure. The training is awesome, they really strive to have very well integrated teams, and they're huge on feedback from all levels of employees. They are also super flexible with your schedule and managers work closely with you to help you out. And you only have to tip out 1% of your sales to the bartender.
Cons_x: They are so picky with who they hire that they have a hard time staying fully staffed.The way that they do sections (you can have 10 tables at a time) makes it really difficult to provide awesome customer service, and they hold you responsible for it. Also you work with a partner in your section, so if you partner is struggling then that can get you behind. So overall you'll make money because you have so many tables, but people can really be jerks because you just don't have time to pay attention to them as soon as they decide they need water.
Advice to Management_x: Figure out ways to hire more quickly so that sections can be a more manageable size for servers. Also don't hold servers responsible for subpar service when servers are given half of the dining room between them and their partner.

Pros_x: Fast paced fun job. You can make money as a server in a Chili's, you just have to move fast and give the customers a reason to love you.
Cons_x: Times are tough, so people are not going out as much. While you will make money, you will have to budget carefully so that the lean times will not break you. My store in upstate NY was a tough place to make money in January.
Advice to Management_x: Take some time to teach your store managers the skill of coaching. There seems to be great opportunity to coach employees rather than just disciplining them when something goes wrong.

Advice to Management_x: Schedule and promote by performance, not favorites.

Title_x: "Learn the difference between SERVER and SERVANT.."
Pros_x: Flexible hours, friendly co-workers, benefits are available but not really worth it if you're in a tipped position. Room for growth, team work is enforced through a "team service" system.
Cons_x: Way too lenient with guests. Guests are allowed to use expired coupons, multiple coupons for one visit, which brings the check average down resulting in less money for the servers.
Advice to Management_x: Management should be more vigilant about using their discretion on a case by case basis and learn how to identify guests who repeatedly take advantage of the system because it directly effects the bottom line profit of the overall business.

Title_x: "Good Money for a college student or recent college grad looking for a career."
Pros_x: Flexble hours, fun atmosphere, get paid cash every shift you work, company offers insurance plans (not good though) Company promotes within. If you aspire to become a manager or bartender then prove your abilities to management and let your aspirations and goals be known. Great for a 2nd job or weekend job, 1/2 off your check when visiting other Brinker Restaurants, Constant feedback from guests survey's so you know what works and what needs improvment. Great charity work especially for St. Jude's Children's Research Hospital, and give back nights. Large sections to maxamize your income and incentives to sell promotional items. I was lucky enough to work with mostly amazing managers
Cons_x: Long hours with no breaks (if working a double straight through) Some stores have excellent managers but I have worked with terrible managers which makes the shift a nightmare. Having to follow franchise rules "perfect 10" to every table in fear of being secret shopped. Gem should not determine how well a store is doing. I understand the importance but it should not be the be all end all. Employees have a very limited menu to choose from if they want to pay 1/2 off their meal for break. Horrible insurance plans for part-time, full-time, and managers. Every store is different but if you have a terrible manager you know the shift is not going to be fun/organized.
Advice to Management_x: Keep doing the great charity work, especially for St. Jude's. The Brinker Family Fund is an amazing program and should always remain part of Brinker. Lighten up a little bit when it comes to GEM, sometimes it's hard to get people to go home and fill out surveys. Management crew should be consistent when it comes to policy, I've seen conflicting policies for closing duties and other policies between diffrent managers. One manager would get upset because you did something that the previous manager instructed you to do. Overall I think Chili's is a great job w/ potential to make it a career if you want to however, the insurance plans are just awful.
Pros_y: Good pay, learn new ways of doing things.
Cons_y: Horrible Health Ins. No balance of work and home

Title_x: "Good Money for a college student or recent college grad looking for a career."
Pros_x: Flexble hours, fun atmosphere, get paid cash every shift you work, company offers insurance plans (not good though) Company promotes within. If you aspire to become a manager or bartender then prove your abilities to management and let your aspirations and goals be known. Great for a 2nd job or weekend job, 1/2 off your check when visiting other Brinker Restaurants, Constant feedback from guests survey's so you know what works and what needs improvment. Great charity work especially for St. Jude's Children's Research Hospital, and give back nights. Large sections to maxamize your income and incentives to sell promotional items. I was lucky enough to work with mostly amazing managers
Cons_x: Long hours with no breaks (if working a double straight through) Some stores have excellent managers but I have worked with terrible managers which makes the shift a nightmare. Having to follow franchise rules "perfect 10" to every table in fear of being secret shopped. Gem should not determine how well a store is doing. I understand the importance but it should not be the be all end all. Employees have a very limited menu to choose from if they want to pay 1/2 off their meal for break. Horrible insurance plans for part-time, full-time, and managers. Every store is different but if you have a terrible manager you know the shift is not going to be fun/organized.
Advice to Management_x: Keep doing the great charity work, especially for St. Jude's. The Brinker Family Fund is an amazing program and should always remain part of Brinker. Lighten up a little bit when it comes to GEM, sometimes it's hard to get people to go home and fill out surveys. Management crew should be consistent when it comes to policy, I've seen conflicting policies for closing duties and other policies between diffrent managers. One manager would get upset because you did something that the previous manager instructed you to do. Overall I think Chili's is a great job w/ potential to make it a career if you want to however, the insurance plans are just awful.
Pros_y: Good pay, learn new ways of doing things.
Cons_y: Horrible Health Ins. No balance of work and home

Pros_x: Great staff, consistent strong sales while in season, 50% off all Brinker locations on your days off, minimal micro management (managers really just let you run your own section), very easy menu, next to nothing tip out, fun environment, non profit account set up so you can donate money for co workers in time of need, online training, very very very good at scheduling, plenty of stores to transfer to, extremely easy job in case you're ever hungover.
Cons_x: Basing your company on dirt cheap prices does not always make a business thrive and neither does the motto "the customer is always right." Chili's brand has certainly gone down in recent years and has even been realized as a joke place in movies. As a company that used to compete well in the casual dining market, to date, they seem to rely on price points, round numbers, as well as cutting the fat to save every cent possible. You almost feel embarrassed saying you work here and you can thank the 2 for $20 for the run down decor and equipment of the restaurant. I doubt Chili's will be in business by the time inflation hits food prices hard. It's a shame they look so broke but they have to save every cent to make any money at all off their flagship product. The 2 for $20 will be the number one thing you sell by the way, and it will make your blood boil serving it to people who don't understand proper restaurant etiquette. Your clientele will consist of people who are extreme cheapskates and will be so rude because they don't get to go out often and take the opportunity to demand what they want. Customers also know that managers will do whatever the customer wants. I had a lady once ask for a discount, so when I asked if there was a problem she simply replied "because the customer is always right" so my manager discounted her 10 percent off. Your tips average 8-10% due to the higher end clientele going to better establishments. Your kitchen is also extremely incompetent and they base scheduling in the slow season off of your GEM score. (Basically a guest review of their experience) so if they had a problem with their food out of your control and admit that, you in turn will be blamed because it came up as a problem under your name, which isn't fair because it may not be your problem in the first place i.e kitchen mistake or food tasted bad.
Advice to Management_x: I have no advice to senior management at all, I just have hope. It's already a sinking ship and I just pray that you keep this vessel afloat long enough before the 2 for $20 goes bye bye.
Pros_y: Good pay, learn new ways of doing things.
Cons_y: Horrible Health Ins. No balance of work and home

Pros_x: Pay based on my work ethic and workable hours.
Cons_x: The shifts can be late hours.

They have a maximum amount of health insurance they provide to employees so most can't get insurance from here. I asked for health insurance coverage after working at least 30 hours a week for over a year and was told I would get my hours cut to 2 shifts a week so I wouldn't be eligible anymore.
Advice to Management_x: Take some consideration to your employees. You can't keep cutting what little perks there are to this job and expect your company to thrive through hardwork provided by your employees.

Pros_x: It's nice to be able to walk out with a chunk of cash at the end of every shift, and if you get along with your team members it's fun to work there. At coors i40 you can walk out on a weekday with at least $100, and on the weekends even more. Scheduling is semi-flexible, and most managers are super cool.
Cons_x: G.M.'s are mostly full of bull. Corporate is about the bottom line, not the people, they don't care what you do or how you do it, just keep your comps down and sales up. There are super stupid contests they have quarterly, even if you win you won't win anything. You could come in at 3:00 to open dinner and end up closing on the map, meaning you won't get out until midnight or later. Be prepared, a lot of customers are jerks too.
Advice to Management_x: Help the servers out. Quit hiding in the office, or talking to your buddies at the bar, help us do our job by doing yours. To upper management: we are humans, not mules or robots, remember that when pushing us on our bottom lines.

Title_x: "Horrible customers, near impossible expectations & long hours"
Pros_x: Money was decent- anywhere from $10/hr to $20+. Depends on night + section scheduled. Great coworkers. My store was a cohesive unit (for the most part) that took teamwork seriously. We all threw job titles aside to get the job done. Servers helped wash dishes, line cooks would help bus tables, etc.
Cons_x: The clientele is hideous. Expect to be cursed at, threatened and basically treated like crap. The police department was called so many times to handle irrational guests that they basically refused to answer our calls and we hired a private security firm.. . You will be expected to run a 5-9 table section without proper supplies. Essentials like having clean silverware are a rarity. Normally I'd arrive for my shift and have to immediately wash, sort, re-wash and roll silverware. That's while you're getting quadruple sat, have no clean cups, plates, ice or tea brewed fresh. Absolute nightmare. At the end of your shift, you had to roll an additional 100 pieces of silver on top of your 1-2 hours sidework.. . Keep in mind Chilis runs LOW labor. There's one dishwasher at MOST. Usually Mon-Fri Lunch you wash dishes yourself. Servers do ALL of the cleaning besides the line. This means all front of house (clean tables, booths, floors, etc.) plus a majority of the line including kitchen floors, all beverage stations, etc. As a closer on a Saturday night, expect to arrive at 3:30 and leave at 2:30 AM with about $120 in tips if you're lucky.
Advice to Management_x: Give the employees the supplies they need and stop punishing servers for bad GEM scores. It's not the server's fault if a guest complains about the noise volume of the dining room or how under cooked their Ribeye is, or that their Country Fried Steak is fried!
Pros_y: Flexible schedule. Good bonus.
Cons_y: Not really open to feedback. Want yes men .
Advice to Management_y: Upper management should do N undercover boss episode. Maybe 2

Title_x: "Great Brand, Great Culture, Plenty of room for improvement."
Pros_x: Great people, very innovative re-imaging, great food and established brand. Well-oiled machine when Team Service is truly implemented. Great culture and concept which creates a fun work environment, which in turn translates to great customer experience. Decent pay (tips) and plenty of opportunities to move forward within the company. Food discounts and fun promotions.
Cons_x: If one part of the team fails, the machine falls apart. Management seems pressured to run bare-bones, and team members usually have to pick up the slack, which creates a disconnect in trust between management and staff. Difficulties prioritizing staff needs versus business needs, and poor utilization of staff strengths and weaknesses at times. Difficulties in consistent scheduling and a lot of inconvenient last-minute schedule changes.
Advice to Management_x: Chili's has a great concept in place, and people who really believe in the long-standing culture. As long as management sincerely shares this with the team members, things work great. When they fall apart though, it's bad, really bad.
Pros_y: Flexible schedule. Good bonus.
Cons_y: Not really open to feedback. Want yes men .
Advice to Management_y: Upper management should do N undercover boss episode. Maybe 2

Title_x: "Worst job I've ever had...and I've shoveled goat manure for a living."
Pros_x: Those who worked in the front of the house seemed slightly happier with their jobs than those of us at the back. Though I couldn't tell you for sure. They did make more money. It's not a bad place to eat, I never saw food being handled unsafely or bad product being used. Health insurance was available, which is why I stayed as long as I did.
Cons_x: Hired as prep cook, when I started there were three people making/portioning a list of well over 100 items during a shift, in addition to prepping things on the fly for the cooks. Absolutely no breaks. When I started there and asked about breaks they looked at me like I was insane. I was told I could take one if asked but was pressured never to take even a five minute breather. Work was expected to be finished in 8 hours but it usually took 9-10, and that is with three people. One of them was training me so that she could move to another store, so then it was down to two of us. Then our workdays were divided so that only one prep person was working on any given day. All items were expected to be finished in the same amount of time anyway, and I was lectured and written up for taking 12-14 hours to complete what took three people 8-10 hours to finish. They could not understand why I couldn't do it. I worked as hard as I could...I was hungry and tired all day, treated like a servant, frequently ignored when I asked for help lifting a 100lb bag of potatoes or finishing up dishes at the end of the night when I was ready to drop.
Advice to Management_x: Make breaks a requirement where employees have to punch in and out for them so that management has no choice but to schedule employees for at least a meal break or a fifteen minute break. Adjust expectations of how much a single person can do in a particular length of time, and add additional help when additional work is added.
Pros_y: Flexible schedule. Good bonus.
Cons_y: Not really open to feedback. Want yes men .
Advice to Management_y: Upper management should do N undercover boss episode. Maybe 2

Title_x: "Very beneficial learning experience in the corporate food industry"
Pros_x: I enjoyed the stability and always having answer to any question. The pos systems had a button for everything and was very organized and easy to grasp. If you're a responsible employee it's easy to move up.
Cons_x: It was hard to find good employees to stick around considering it was a college town. Managers don't seem to last long. I saw a lot of them get fired in abrupt ways. I worked there for almost 5 years and when I left there were no managers there that had been there since they opened. Managers work long hours and rarely got to see their children.
Advice to Management_x: Keep staff excited to come to work. Set goals and give prizes. Stay on them about sales in a positive way. If you're going to ask someone to do something make sure you are capable of doing it. Micromanagement made employees irate. Be respectful and try to mentor them into moving up with Brinker. That kept a lot of employees around.
Pros_y: Flexible schedule. Good bonus.
Cons_y: Not really open to feedback. Want yes men .

They are not caring when it comes to emergencies and honestly i think they run a bad business when it comes to putting in your two weeks, your better off walking out then trying to work a two weeks. They managers never write up bar tenders or back of house but love to write servers up if someone is wrong with food or bar drinks take too long. BTW bar drinks at chilis average 10-15 minutes
Advice to Management_x: Move up the servers that are knowledgeable. Don't make a server a trainer if they cant even close the restaurant by them selves. and be more sympathetic when it comes to family issues instead of acting like you dont give a flip. oh and my advice to corporate tell managers to quit letting certain servers dont their own voids and comps and making other servers wait 20 minutes. oh and get off your butts at 0890 and do your job!
