Title_x: "Chili's is a great overall company to work for. They offer good benefits, even to part-time employees."
Pros_x: The management really seems to care about their employees. Scheduling is flexible and you have the potential to earn good money. The training is thorough. Learning the menu is a must. This restaurant definitely gets busy towards the end of the week and of course on weekends. As a server I usually go into weekend shifts knowing that I'll be overwhelmed. I just try my best to "stay out of the weeds". Chili's has section partners, so you and you're partner are usually taking care of around 10-12 tables. Team work is a must to make it through a busy shift.
Cons_x: Petty bickering between employees. Reminds me of a high school atmosphere, though I'm sure this problem occurs in every job regardless of the setting. The amount of side work is ridiculous. They don't employ bussers or silverware rollers so be prepared to restock, bus your own tables, roll silverware, sweep the floors, clean table tops, and then there's your actual side work left to do.

Title_x: "Lots of work, often little pay, management plays "favorites""
Pros_x: There is not many opportunities in a rural town so always busy during weekends. Brinker International invests a lot of money in innovation and training and there is always a new drink or food item to sell which keeps things from getting old. If you don't like the restaurant you are at you can always transfer anywhere in the US. Promotions happen from within.
Cons_x: Managers do not treat all employees a like. Often there is one person working and multiple people standing around watching or doing nothing. Some managers do not help employees when they need it.Team service is supposed to be the role of servers but employees rarely help each other out. GEM surveys are a priority and if you are not delivering the number of surveys the corporation thinks you should then the management will bring you in for early Sunday morning meetings to go over ways in which you can get guests to fill them out. This is especially unfair when you close on a Saturday night and go to church with your family. Also, in a small town, there are not as many people to ask and the same people do not want to continually do them. They take 10 min or more.
Advice to Management_x: Don't be buddies to certain employees and a boss to others. Be a mentor to everyone and practice what you preach always.
Pros_y: Chilis is a company that cares about people and the lives of people. Flexible work hours with only 5 shifts a week as a manager. Great benifits.
Cons_y: Just like with most large companies, the work load is pretty heavy. Expectations are very high and the days are sometimes long due to the lack of manpower at times.
Advice to Management_y: Consider dropping business rules or at least make them within reach in order to maintain facility as well as TM satisfaction.

Title_x: "Great coworkers horrible customer base. Terrible to no tips on most acceptable to good on few."
Pros_x: The best reason to work at this location is the management and employees. All are welcome regardless of age or past.
Cons_x: The customer base varies so much that the tips are unpredictable and you almost always have to close to insure a profitable night.
Advice to Management_x: Keep the riff raff out, continue to support your staff but remember those who work the hardest and are not just the favorites or the prettiest.

Laid back work atmosphere, uniforms easy to wear (not restricting, no dry cleaning or ironing needed) clientele generally easy going, good tips, can be a fun place to work if you have the right attitude.
Cons_x: Might take you a while to get prime stations like cocktail/bar area or closer. Benefits weren't that great when I worked there, but things may have changed.
Advice to Management_x: Watch for the hard workers and reward them with the good shifts rather than solely giving them to people who've been there longer.

Cons_y: Just like with most large companies, the work load is pretty heavy. Expectations are very high and the days are sometimes long due to the lack of manpower at times.
Advice to Management_y: Consider dropping business rules or at least make them within reach in order to maintain facility as well as TM satisfaction.

Title_x: "Fellow employees hold the key to you happiness"
Pros_x: Great opportunities to build team working skills. Friendly atmosphere, most everyone is very willing to help when needed. Compensation determines how much you put in. You will see higher tips if you put in the work.
Cons_x: Some managers can make the job more difficult than it should be.
Advice to Management_x: Be friendly with your employees and your store will run more smoothly. Don't be dictators. Happy employees don't make mistakes. Happy employees make customers happy, make more money themselves, and more money for the store.

Title_x: "Regardless of dedication you will go nowhere"
Pros_x: Semi-Flexible hours. Depending of the restaurant, you could make decent money even if your managers didn't like you. Always understaffed so you'll always have plenty of hours.
Cons_x: They hire incompetent managers and promote favorites instead of dedicated and hardworking employees. Seniority will get you everywhere even if you don't work hard. Unorganized when shifting leadership. Overworks kitchen staff.
Advice to Management_x: You need to have a third party come in and monitor employees before choosing who to promote solely based on the store management team. Really see who is doing the work, not who the management favors. There is way to much bias at all 5 locations I've worked at around Texas.

Pros_x: There were no pros for working here if you have an opportunity to manage elsewhere. Starting with the GM, upper management focuses more on keeping and justifying their job that they micro manage store managers. The profit matrix is so stiff that they don't take into account outside influences on business, such as living in a college town, weather, road construction, etc.
Cons_x: Upper management has unrealistic expectations for metrics like food cost and labor yet offers no options or tools to help manage them.
Advice to Management_x: Trust your store managers to tell the truth about your operations as much as your GM's and hourly employees. Maybe you won't have so much turn over. Also, 55 hours a week for 40k isn't conducive to good customer service.

Advice to Management_x: Bring some quality of life initiatives back!

Title_x: "I just started about two weeks ago and I can honestly already say I love my job!"
Pros_x: Great management, great environment. Most of my coworkers are extremely friendly and we work great as a team. Since I've started, we've been pretty busy almost every day that I work so I'm not easily bored. The food is delicious and the customers are super friendly!
Cons_x: servers take forever to bus their tables, so it makes the hosts job harder. A couple of my fellow hostesses are lazy and just stand at the host stand and never actually seat customers or wipe off tables so I'm stuck running around the restaurant trying to seat loads of customers on my own.
Advice to Management_x: Make sure that all employees are doing an equal share of work throughout the day/night so that all the pressure to keep up with the crowd isn't on one single person.
Pros_y: They are flexible on scheduling. Always get two weeks vacation. Benefits are there if you want them. All around solid company.
Cons_y: Long hours are rough minimum 50 hour work week for management. If you have a day you need to leave early they make you make up the hours. Insurance is really expensive.
Advice to Management_y: Bring some quality of life initiatives back!

Title_x: "Overall good, although a TON of change at above restaurant level leadership"
Pros_x: Just a great company to work for. I have had a great 10+ year job that has allowed me to meet a ton of people. The pay is good, the company has a good work life ratio on paper (more on that in the cons) and for the most part, upper leadership are top notch PEOPLE, not just bosses.
Cons_x: Occasional disconnect at AD level. That is the biggest issue I have had. Work life separation is non existent to some of them. Phone calls on days off when your restaurant is running great numbers. I would ALMOST understand the harassment if you were under performing, but some of them can't leave their GMP team be. Almost like they are looking to try to push you out.
Advice to Management_x: Better vetting of AD level position. Yes, results matter, but not at the expense of the company culture.
Pros_y: Great culture! Great place to work
Cons_y: Hours didn't work when I had a kiddo and my husband was out of town a lot. Not Chilis fault just my personal situation
Advice to Management_y: Na

Title_x: "It's a job. An insecure one, but a job."
Pros_x: You make money based on how well your customer service skills are, as is with any hospitality job. There are small incentive programs that make work more fun, and the service staff is comprised of very awesome people. I would recommend this job to someone that has previous hospitality experience.
Cons_x: Poor training. New hires with minimal to no hospitality experience never made it longer than two months. The training program appears to have been designed thoughtfully with a fun and humorous tone to help new hires, but becomes complex and confusing, making it difficult for new hires to grasp, especially when it is administered by unconcerned servers/ bartenders that want to rush through the steps and get back to their jobs. Also, the menu is constantly changing, constantly making the older menus and training guides outdated. This makes it confusing for a new hire who is learning about old sandwiches that are not on the menu anymore, instead of learning about the new ones that are. Management seems to be more involved with checking on tables for negativity to throw at the employees, than spending time with them engaging, encouraging, teaching, training, and developing. Also, management is quick to let employees go without necessary documentation (i.e. counseling, written notices, suspension, etc.) which may hurt one day when you find an employee intelligent and determined enough to seek legal advice about being improperly terminated after one year of employment without any prior counseling.
Advice to Management_x: Become more involved with your staff and ensure that training is completely understood by new hires, and everyone is in sync with current menu items and promotions, without being too critical if they don't know everything on the second day. Remember, you're going to be questionable and stressed out jumping out of a plane, if you're not completely sure of how to use the parachute.
Pros_y: Great culture! Great place to work
Cons_y: Hours didn't work when I had a kiddo and my husband was out of town a lot. Not Chilis fault just my personal situation
Advice to Management_y: Na

Title_x: "Good job to have in college, but not long term"
Pros_x: Flexible hours, easy to set your schedule, easy to request days off
Cons_x: Managers come and go so quickly each has a different way to manage it's hard to have a consistent work environment, managers often belittle the staff
Advice to Management_x: Encourage your staff don't belittle them, have more team building exercises so it doesn't turn into a high school popularity contest where there is less team work yet more drama , have the management all on one page by being consistent to what is of top priority and what is secondary and so on and so forth
Pros_y: Great culture! Great place to work
Cons_y: Hours didn't work when I had a kiddo and my husband was out of town a lot. Not Chilis fault just my personal situation
Advice to Management_y: Na

Pros_x: Good pay compared to competition, Pretty decent hours depending on location, Good culture, Great tools to get the numbers you need and see what you need to do to improve.
Cons_x: Hard labor plan, you will definitely spend a very decent amount of time in position, a lot of the time it is dishwashing, hopping on the line and cooking, or out front bussing tables and running food. High turnover rate.
Advice to Management_x: Worry a little less about maxing out your bonus, and a little more about keeping your current guests and employees happy.

Pros_x: As a server you get a good amount of tables. Around 4-8 tables at a time. Which leads to more money, the management is wonderful, in my opinion, because they're laid back, but will be stern if needed.
Cons_x: The only con I could see is if a server wasn't able to keep up. And that's not the company's fault, but their own.
Pros_y: Fun staff. Fast pace. High energy. Front of house shifts were decent most of the time.
Cons_y: Spend most of your time cooking. Everything was microwaved due to no time to prep and cook properly. Managers always having to work in kitchen. Constant issues in the kitchen lead to having to comp a lot of things, then you get in trouble for comping things. Constant high stress level. Women and single employees are treated better than those married with kids and men.. Absolutely no concern for quality of life. Too many menu changes. Even the full time kitchen employees don't know the ingredients. But hey, they just throw them in the microwave anyway. Chili's does not care about employees or customers, only the bottom line. I worked for multiple Chili's in multiple states. I thought it was bad in my original area, but is worse in other areas.
Advice to Management_y: Stop trying to think of grand new ideas and start caring even one ounce about your employees and customers. Stop caring so much about shareholders, they will be happy if your customers are happy. Fire the board, president, and everyone at the top and hire someone with a brain. Maybe someone from Chic-fil-A. Probably the lowest paid person at Chic-fil-A or In-N-Out could run this company better.

Pros_x: free food if you worked a double shift. 50% off all chili's and maggiano's restaurants. certain discounts on products such as consoles, cars, etc.
Cons_x: I had 4 managers that never seemed to communicate with each other and each wanted different things from us. i was a host, so I was the first to deal with customers and had direct communication with the managers via headset. One manager never had hers on so I always had to run to the back to find her, leaving the door unattended thus getting yelled at by impatient guests. No tip out system although the hosts were also bussers. They got rid of bussers so it's up to the servers to clean their stations but most of the time they didn't. We were a very high volume store, yet we were severly understaffed. I worked 6 day weeks usually 9 hours a day. One manager yelled at me for staying overtime even though the other manager didn't give me a break and asked me to stay later. Goes to show how well everyone communicated. Just overall an awful experience, and I left crying many nights. Also, on a busy Friday night I had an awful server who couldn't handle more than 3 tables at a time and cursed me out in front of all our guests yet the manager that night did not do anything to handle the situation because they were in a sexual relationship. Worst place I've ever worked at and would not recommend to anyone.
Advice to Management_x: You all preach communication yet when it comes down to it, no one cares and seems to do things their own way. Train your staff better, and don't keep a high volume store so understaffed that you overwork the workers you do have, and then yell at them for working too much.

Women and single employees are treated better than those married with kids and men.. Absolutely no concern for quality of life. Too many menu changes. Even the full time kitchen employees don't know the ingredients. But hey, they just throw them in the microwave anyway. Chili's does not care about employees or customers, only the bottom line. I worked for multiple Chili's in multiple states. I thought it was bad in my original area, but is worse in other areas.
Advice to Management_y: Stop trying to think of grand new ideas and start caring even one ounce about your employees and customers. Stop caring so much about shareholders, they will be happy if your customers are happy. Fire the board, president, and everyone at the top and hire someone with a brain. Maybe someone from Chic-fil-A. Probably the lowest paid person at Chic-fil-A or In-N-Out could run this company better.

Cons_x: Managers work too many positions and are way to hands on. Just as much time catering to team members as the guest. Too much change in menu, initiatives and procedures and recipes.
Advice to Management_x: Stop catering to team members and focus more on guest. Managers should supervise and be less hands on. Quit changing everything so often.

Title_x: "Laid back atmosphere but not worth it at times."
Pros_x: -good pay (when busy). -fun people to work with. -flexible schedule and easy to ask off. -good discount on food for employees
Cons_x: -Intense promotion of GEM surveys that could lead to you not being scheduled if you don't get enough. -St. Jude fundraiser in September is great but customers are absolutely bombarded. I wouldn't donate either.. -Management plays favorites. -Shifts can be very long
Advice to Management_x: Stop being so money hungry. I had a manager tell me they don't give discounts to soldiers in uniform because they don't have a gun. And guns can protect us if we get robbed. That's why police officers on duty get a discount.

Cons_x: i was very comfortable in every aspect of working for my company.

Title_x: "GREAT management, stressful work environment, WONDERFUL PEPPER PALS/MANAGERS that work as a team! Good food:)"
Pros_x: Never got denied a raise, worked around my student schedule, and genuinely cared about the employees. Good FOOD and good "team-bonding" outings!
Cons_x: Stressful workplace, not enough people on busy nights, and sometimes strict on rules on when you can have food discounts.
Advice to Management_x: Make your regional/uppermost management work there on a busy Fri/Sat/Sun few times a year and personally employees what they need!

Pros_x: Awesome food. Friendly management staff. Decent hours
Cons_x: No room for advancement. High turn over rate. Lack of teamwork in both FOH & BOH
Advice to Management_x: Pay people what they are worth, and they will be loyal.. Pay them what you agreed at hire, and you may find their worth.. Overwork and underpay them, and then you find yourself starting from scratch...again.

Title_x: "Like any other serving job, but with more side work"
Pros_x: Can have a good schedule, good pay if you get good clientele, people are fun to work with, food is awesome
Cons_x: Scheduling issues (but this is specific to the store I work at), restaurant is open late, a lot of side work - often takes an hour and a half to two hours to leave the store after you're cut - asked to perform non-server tasks when closing (i.e. scrubbing the floors), often get bad clientele, but that's to be expected when you work in corporate/franchise
Advice to Management_x: Look at your staff's availability, and schedule them within it. If you make changes to the schedule, let us know ahead of time, don't try to appease everybody because that negatively affects someone else. Get better cooks so that servers don't have to be held accountable for kitchen errors. Pay attention to labor and actually cut servers when it's slow. More consistency overall

Advice to Management_y: Stop catering to team members and focus more on guest. Managers should supervise and be less hands on. Quit changing everything so often.

Pros_x: This company was great to work for, the money for the work was great, I learned a lot really fast, they hired me without previous experience
Cons_x: It is a customer service oriented job and every customer service job has to deal with bad customers at times.

Title_x: "ERJ Dining is a decent employer to work for."
Pros_x: Opportunities for advancement, benefits, everyday is different, paid vacation, tuition reimbursement, good co-workers, salaried, opportunity for raises yearly, six paid sick days
Cons_x: Very long hours, at least 10 hour shifts, required to work 50-55 hours weekly, always changing policies, no overtime pay when working more than required hours
Advice to Management_x: Needs more structured advancement program, management and employee training programs are very unorganized. When rolling out new food items the kinks should be better worked out before going to store level. Some policies not clear, too much leeway and guesswork when disciplining employees. Back office computers very old and slow, hindering completing your responsibilities.

Title_x: "Pretty standard, as far as chain restaurants go, but a good place to make quick money."
Pros_x: Out of all the chain restaurants, Chili's is one of the easiest to make quick money at. The sections are set up so that most good servers are able to get A LOT of tables at once, (sometimes almost overwhelmingly so). Tip out is also minimal compared to other restaurants so that you keep most of the money you are making.
Cons_x: This is sort of common for the industry but management rotation is frequent and communication between managers is often very poor.
Advice to Management_x: Communicate better with servers about the extent of their expectations.
Title_y: "ERJ Dining is a decent employer to work for."
Pros_y: Opportunities for advancement, benefits, everyday is different, paid vacation, tuition reimbursement, good co-workers, salaried, opportunity for raises yearly, six paid sick days

When rolling out new food items the kinks should be better worked out before going to store level. Some policies not clear, too much leeway and guesswork when disciplining employees. Back office computers very old and slow, hindering completing your responsibilities.

Pros_x: Chili's takes you in like a family. Though there are new rollouts of food almost every month, the company helps notify servers and managers in a timely manner to get their staff ready for new items. Managers, for the most part, are great with helping your shift go smoothly and dealing with stressful situations. I have been an employee for almost 5 years while going to school and Chili's has always been flexible with my schedule. Chili's is like a new family and I highly recommend working here if you enjoy the service industry.
Cons_x: Only con I can think of is the menu changes a lot, but that is about it.

Title_x: "grear opportunity if you are willing to work hard and work smart."
Pros_x: People can be generous with their tips. It's normal to make $150 a day on weekends. Coworkers are fun. If you work hard, you can be promoted to higher positions
Cons_x: You never see a paycheck due to taxes. Food industry requires long, arduous hours. Customers can treat you badly. Stressful environment
Advice to Management_x: Positive reinforcement goes a long way, especially when employees have to spend so much time receiving with the potential negativity of guests.

Cons_y: 1 weekend off a month

Pros_x: Great co-workers (I've worked at two stores)! Some flexibility. Can make a lot of money. 50% discount (1-4 guests) when you're off and eat at Chili's (any).
Cons_x: Not a guaranteed job. Not a for sure you'll walk away with consistent money. Can get really stressful. Smell like food after work. Late nights.
Advice to Management_x: Keep promoting people!!! This helps people stay motivated! Give bonuses, stop being stingy.

Pros_x: co-workers and that's about it

Title_x: "Loyalty is not one of their numerous "culture""
Pros_x: Can make money if you hustle, but you really have to hustle. managers are told they work 10hr days, but it's more like 15.
Cons_x: -long work hours for minimal recognition. -corporate loves you one day and then hates you the next. -too bottom line and making numbers focused. -servers are children, have to hold their hands to get anything accomplished. -managers end up doing everything; bussing for the staff, running food, hosting, taking orders, and bartending all while trying to place their own orders, office work, and cooking all at the same time.
Advice to Management_x: You won't like working there

Pros_x: Chili's is very thorough with their training and flexible on scheduling. I started working there when I was a student and continued after graduation while deciding what my next step would be. It was a fun work environment, but maintained structure to keep things moving.
Cons_x: I agree with a previous reviewer that too much emphasis was placed on the customer surveys. Before the ziosks, it took an extra effort for surveys to be completed, so only customers who had a very strong opinion either way would be compelled to do so. The restaurant/servers also only got credit for 5s (scale 1-5) even though 4s still represented above average scores.
Advice to Management_x: Overall, management did a very good job. I recall there being problems with promotions/ shifts being promised to multiple employees where there was only room for one, which caused more disappointments than was necessary.
Title_y: "Loyalty is not one of their numerous "culture""

Title_x: "Serving is stressful, lots of side work."
Pros_x: We have a lot of regulars and I love my co workers and managers. Money is best on the week days when the grill can handle the crowd and the clientele are a bit more high class than on the weekends.
Cons_x: SO MUCH SIDE WORK. Many hours cleaning and rolling silverware, all at 2.13 an hour. Plates and trays are very heavy, so I ache. All the time.
Advice to Management_x: Fire the people who are incapable of doing their jobs. This is not a charity. It's very frustrating when my tips go down because the grill can't get food out. Servers get dogged out more for customer dissatisfaction than the grill does-even though it's the grills fault.

Title_x: "Company is fine, just had a bad manager"
Pros_x: The opportunity to get tips and get more than minimum wage. Met a lot of interesting people. Some would invite me to sit with them while I took their order or share a desert with them. Co-workers were also nice.
Cons_x: Our manager didn't know how to schedule people. We either had too few cooks or too many servers on the floor. One Friday night I only had two tables for the entire night. On a Friday! I asked the manager if I could get more hours and she said "It's not how many hours you work, it's how you work the tables." You can't really work much money out of two tables.
Advice to Management_x: I'm not sure if the same managers are still working there. Just make sure that one of them knows how to schedule people so they can get enough tables.

Advice to Management_x: Make sure that you continue seeking your employees feedback as they are the boots on the ground, especially when rolling out new items.

Advice to Management_y: You won't like working there

Pros_x: Great place to meet life long friends
Cons_x: Hectic work environment. Very long hours with little sleep.
Advice to Management_x: Takes awhile. They dangle a carrot in front of you so you keep doing a great job for them.

Pros_x: Coworkers are great although over worked also.
Cons_x: Corporate expects managers to cook and do hourly functions all day to save money. All they care about is the bottom line. No concern for the staff. Bonuses are almost impossible to obtain, no sick days, no holiday pay etc.
Advice to Management_x: Corporate needs to show appreciation for the people working in the field. Start caring about the people making your money.

Title_x: "I found the company Chili's to not be overly caring about their employees, but many of my coworkers were so great."
Pros_x: - You make a fair amount of tips. - You are usually not too bored, at least at nights. - If you are going to school, it works well because you can just work nights and weekends
Cons_x: - They would rather fire you than pay overtime. - The restaurant business is not always the most rewarding. - You only get your schedule 3 to 4 days before you start working that week
Advice to Management_x: Please, please, please when we ask something off, honor it! One of the most stressful things about working here was not knowing until 3 days beforehand if the special day you requested off 2 months ago was actually going to work out.

Title_x: "Very bipolar place to work, because one day you will love it, but the next day you will hate it."
Pros_x: Flexible scheduling, steady flow of people to serve, decent money if you are good at your job. Meeting many awesome people that come in for service or work along side you.
Cons_x: Lack of care for the well being of employees from management expressed through both action and words. Unsafe working environment. This restaurant also attracts some people that are very difficult to work with and serve.
Advice to Management_x: Care about people more then selling your product including guests and employees. Priorities are unethical from my perspective. People are more important then money. Without people you will not generate any revenue.
Title_y: "Love the people, not always the job."
Pros_y: Working at Chili's is never boring.. . The 401k is great. They offer a 5% match on 6% invested. That's one of the best 401ks around.. . The culture is great.. . The brand is growing and doing very well.
Cons_y: Work/life balance is something that seems impossible in the restaurant industry. While they have tested some ideas in certain markets like investing in a larger management staff to accommodate more time off they have failed to roll this forward. Turnover for managers seems to remain fairly high.. . Most areas do not ever become "fully staffed" and when there is a shortage the rest of the area is called on to help cover. This means you will be away from your home for a couple of nights each month until things get back to normal.. . Career opportunities are lacking. Becoming a restaurant manager is very attainable. A general manager position is attainable if you are willing to move. Anything past that the company is stagnant. From the area director level up there is not a lot of moving pieces. That results in general managers that have been in their role for 10+ years everywhere. It's hard for these people to remain passionate about what they do when they have not been challenged in years.
Advice to Management_y: Find a way to fix work/life balance.

Title_x: "Mixed bag, people were diverse and interesting, younger immature management team."
Pros_x: Great food discount that can be used nationwide, availability of benefits. With the right "zone partner" and kitchen crew there is plenty of money to be made.
Cons_x: Childish inexperienced managers who were ineffective leaders. Staff walked on and took advantage of them. Descriminatory remarks made by another server about guests were overlooked when I approached managers and I ended up without a job.
Advice to Management_x: Grow a set and lead. Getting rid of someone who is offended by inappropriate remarks of others isn't right. This is 2015 NOT 1955 where remarks regarding a person's skin tone or the genders of the guests is not cool.

Pros_x: Flexible schedule, good benefits, Promote from with in, always expanding and looking for new innovative ideas to grow company.
Cons_x: Expected to work long hours. Job is not conducive for a family person. Expected to work on days off if need to. Expected to work every hourly position if need to.
Advice to Management_x: Its a good company but be prepared to work long hard hours. As a manager you will work hourly positions and you will work well over 55 hours a week. Many of the hours will not be spent in the building.

Pros_x: great atmosphere, flexible scheduling, heading in a great direction with this brand
Cons_x: GWAP (guest with a problem) is unfair. It is based on a survey that guests take on the ziosk after payment and it asks if there was a problem... A LOT of problems have to do with food correctness and how long the food took which is a problem with the kitchen not the servers and yet we still get the slack from our percentage of guests with a problem while the kitchen hears nothing of it....
Advice to Management_x: Don't have blatantly obvious favorites and hold the kitchen accountable for the GWAPs that they cause

Cons_x: GWAP (guest with a problem) is unfair. It is based on a survey that guests take on the ziosk after payment and it asks if there was a problem... A LOT of problems have to do with food correctness and how long the food took which is a problem with the kitchen not the servers and yet we still get the slack from our percentage of guests with a problem while the kitchen hears nothing of it....
Advice to Management_x: Don't have blatantly obvious favorites and hold the kitchen accountable for the GWAPs that they cause

Title_x: "High turn over rate for a reason"
Pros_x: You get a 50% discount on food when working. They work with your school schedule if you are a student.
Cons_x: They do not care about the employee. If you are sick and even if you are throwing up unless you can get someone to work for you and have management to approve it. You will get fired. I have seen employees go to the restroom several times to throw up and come back to continue working. Even when you let management know the employee has been throwing up they tell them to continue to work. Also I have had to go to management because I could not find employees because they are outside taking a long smoke break. And their customers need them. If you are a non smoker you are not allowed to have a non scheduled break. All in all my experience was not pleasant. Most employees do not stay long and do not feel like part of a team.
Advice to Management_x: When you have employees that do work hard and have a proven work record and has a bad couple of weeks due to sickness or emergency. You should be forgiven and they will be loyal to you. And if you have a high turn over rate you should go to employees and figure out why. Value your employees!!!

Title_x: "Just like any other restaurant in that there are good days and bad ones."
Pros_x: -Coming here from a minimum wage gig was great. So long as you get a decent amount of hours, the money is good (*I'm speaking from the standpoint of a college kid). -Free meals on shifts you work. -Good kitchen experience. -Easy, repetitive, mindnumbing work. If you don't get bored easily, or do and don't mind it, you'll be all set
Cons_x: -Managers play favorites. People who have poor work ethics or attitudes still get good/better hours than others... highly annoying. -Prep (everyone who works in the kitchen, really) doesn't get treated fairly. New promotions come along, which equals more things to prep/cook, yet we're hardly ever given a bigger time frame to complete all of our tasks and are instead reprimanded if not finished by a certain time. Your hours can get cut in a moment's notice in order to help labor, yet management generally makes no strides of their own to see what can be done to help you recover some of that lost time.. -Managers can be very lax in disciplining wrongdoings by other team members. They also set goals that are never seen or heard of again. -Early starting time. If you're not a morning person and can't get over it, probably not the best gig for you
Advice to Management_x: LISTEN. TO. YOUR. EMPLOYEES. Realize that not all changes you make are always good ones. Recognize that not everyone can do a truckload of work in less than 8 hours. Dole out punishments to EVERYONE who does something wrong, not just a select few people you don't care for as much. Crack down on EVERYONE when you talk about tightening up, not just a handful of people you don't like. Don't be an a-hole to your workers when they approach you with nothing but respect.
Pros_y: Flexible schedule, good benefits, Promote from with in, always expanding and looking for new innovative ideas to grow company.
Cons_y: Expected to work long hours. Job is not conducive for a family person. Expected to work on days off if need to. Expected to work every hourly position if need to.
Advice to Management_y: Its a good company but be prepared to work long hard hours. As a manager you will work hourly positions and you will work well over 55 hours a week. Many of the hours will not be spent in the building.

Title_x: "If it wasn't for the management and theft I would've stayed."
Pros_x: Money can be very good so long as you have the right shifts and sections
Cons_x: Your forced to pool general manager enforces this by telling you that he can't force you to pool but if you don't the door is right there. So if your stuck working with a lazy or untrustworthy person your screwed. And theft is HUGE problem in this place. Sidework is hell takes about an hr and that's if your not closing also they make you do extra cleaning once a month they call it "BUG NIGHT" and you don't get any extra pay for this or compensation even though your there for hours longer than you would've been. There are no food runners or bussers and you get a 13-15 table section with your partner. Your also getting only a couple $ from each table mostly 10% because of the quality of customers and prices on the menu so your running around like a madman you dont even make the money you should've made for your sales. And if you get stiffed on a bill? Management will actually defend the guests and tell you that they are not required to tip you.Your customers are almost always rude, entitled, and cheap. Oh and don't even bother trying to request days off. Half the time no matter how important you won't get that day off. The turnover rate is very high.
Advice to Management_x: Hire more than just pretty girls and stop sexually harassing them by asking them personal questions about their sex life and even playing "games" such as who would you have sex with its disgusting and most of the staff is 18-25, be proffessional. Don't blame the staff when the kitchen crashes maybe if you helped expo or run food instead of sitting in the office on your phone the weekend shifts wouldn't go so badly. Schedule people fairly not based on favorites. If someone claims they believed they've been robbed don't dismiss this and do something, I'm not saying fire people based on rumors but that's a serious accusation and you should at least look into it. Your very hard on your staff and expect way to much it's a job for most of us not a career so don't pressure us to miss class to go work for you. Even with requests for days off you require us to tell you at least 2 weeks in advance fine but then you deny that request even when it's for something important and we gave you 2 weeks to find a cover for that shift. When an employee quits you make their last 2 weeks hell to the point where most people just stop showing up. Quit being spiteful don't take it to heart everyone needs to move on at some point. Management needs to set an example for their staff.

Pros_x: 50% off food. Flexible hours for students. Can make decent money if the store you work at is high volume.
Cons_x: The amount of side work that is done on $3.10 an hour is ridiculous, also the case with opening shifts. At that time no tips are being made so pay should be minimum wage. It is not fair to make employees do extra work while getting paid next to nothing (sometimes takes more than an hour or two). Like any serving job dealing with the public is hard and you must be a people person. In addition, I feel like pushing the customers to use the Ziosks should not be such a big deal. Yes, it can be convenient if the customer is in a rush and makes the customers feel safe as their card never has to leave the table, however, a lot of people simply want to enjoy their experience out and do not want to cash themselves out. This should not reflect on the server. I once had a table tip me 50% because I did not make them cash out on the ziosk. They told me to tell management that it takes away from the experience. The surveys at the end are also ridiculous because people will not tell you that they had a problem and then say it in the survey. How is that solving anything? Especially if the problem was with the food. I cannot fix the problem if I do not know about it until the next day.. . There is also a lot of favoritism and not enough professionalism. If you work hard you and do well you should get recognized/rewarded. I also felt there was no opportunity to grow in this company as they were always hiring from outside rather than from within. The menu is constantly changing and is pretty large also. Customers get mad when something leaves (cinnamon apples and Caesar salads). There are long hours and no breaks. Sometimes I would get there at 9am and not leave til 10 with no break on doubles. Overall, this is not a job I would recommend for a long period of time.
Advice to Management_x: Listen to customers and employees wants/needs. Stop favoritism and cattiness. Stop being cheap and pay your employees for their work. Promote from within the company

Pros_x: Most of my managers are really great! They work very hard to make customers, and they have no problem busting their butt to help the servers when we get in the weeds. I think that's pretty cool, because you don't see that everywhere. Chili's uses a team service method, which is also convenient ( two people basically take care of a larger amount of tables rather than just having your own set tables). Because of team service, the sections are larger because they assume two people are going to be stopping by and helping each table. if you're partnered with a weak server, team service falls through, because all of a sudden you're taking care of your own tables in addition to all of theirs. This happens to me all the time. Cool method, but it doesn't always work.
Cons_x: Understand coming in to Chili's, we do not have table bussers, food runners, etc. servers do this themselves. Which is cool because the tipout is only to bartender, but it can also keep you very busy doing these things on top of waiting on your tables. The main reason I'm leaving Chili's is because of the crowd it attracts. The Ziosk that sit on the table is basically a flashing light to parents to bring all 10 of their kids to Chili's and I'm running around like crazy for a bill that is barely $50, and I may only get a 10% tip. Cheap people. It's so bad, and please don't be offended if you go to Chili's to eat and you're reading this, because obviously not everyone that comes in is cheap. However, the crowd that came in on Mother's Day was just ridiculous. I made 10% tips ALL DAY. Chili's is a great first job; however, if you want to make real money, I highly recommend you try other places.
Advice to Management_x: Stop worrying so much about GEM. I swear that's ALL my managers care about. If a customer gets pissed off, they say, "don't let them checkout on the Ziosk." In case you don't know what GEM is, it's basically a short survey guests fill out at the end of paying their bill on the Ziosk. The surveys are printed off at the end of each night and managers see all comments/complaints. Corporate sees them as well.

Pros_x: I enjoyed working at Chili's for the first year. I started when I was 20, so it was the first job I was ever making about 30 grand a year, with few bills it allowed me a lot more freedom than I was used to. Chili's employees are also very close, which kept morale high enough for a while. If money and going out drinking after with your coworkers is literally all that matters to you, then you'll love it for about a year. Then things change...
Cons_x: Then you get good at your job, you move up in the ranks and they schedule you a few closing shifts. They see you're good at those and your 4 nights a week, getting out at 9 pm becomes 6 nights a week, 9 hour shifts with no breaks. Because they will only train a few people for these shifts, no one can ever work them for you. Next, the days off you request are unavailable, and you have to work you boyfriend's 21st birthday, and close Christmas Eve, and New Years Eve...then New Years Day, then Valentines Day...and then suddenly you're a "disgruntled employee" because they never listen. Eventually your grades start to slip since you're so exhausted, you ask for time off that you never get. Then when your car breaks down (and you still make it to work!!) they call you a liar. Then, after busting your butt for a year and a half, they fire you on the spot for having prescription medication in your purse and you realize you hated working there all along...
Advice to Management_x: They take their employees for granted. Management bullies you into working shifts and then gets personally offended when you have trouble meeting demands. They don't listen, they kill the morale of their employees and wonder why no one wants to work there. My advice to Brinker International? Do a little looking internally.
Pros_y: ERJ Dining is an employee focused company.
Cons_y: Not enough to make a list.

Pros_x: Met some cool people, and I enjoy prepping food, so that side of it was somewhat ok.
Cons_x: So many things. They have such unrealistic expectations for their prep cooks. I would be handed a list of over 100 things at 8 AM, and then sent off on my own, which isn't the big deal. Its the fact of how much had to be prepped and how little help I got. And I was expected to be done by 2:30 every day. Which never happened. Works lots of 10-16 hour shifts, no breaks.
Advice to Management_x: Communicate with each other before talking to employees, help prep out, try to reduce amount of items on prep list
Pros_y: ERJ Dining is an employee focused company.
Cons_y: Not enough to make a list.

Pros_x: I enjoyed the teamwork and overall family-like connection I had with my coworkers. I actually enjoyed coming in to work.
Cons_x: The work can be very demanding for very little pay.. I've had to bite the bullet on this fact for a few years.
Advice to Management_x: Just be sure that you treat you're employees with respect and don't take advantage of your authority - at the end of the day, we're all human, no one is above anyone else.
Pros_y: The pay is the best in the industry. Great benefits, free meals for you and your family. Good menu, smart marketing. Lots of potential to build a strong customer base at your location. If you enjoy a challenge, you will be challenged.
Cons_y: 50-60 hours a week minimum. You will never get to stop and eat, breaks are non existent. I've yet to meet a manager with a normal family life. The place is a pressure cooker. You are constantly pressured to send your servers, hosts, and cooks home to save on labor, then hope that you don't get a rush because YOU will have to fill all those roles. It's a schizophrenic management strategy that is impossible to win with. You are encouraged to "call workers off" - basically tell them not to come in to work if you feel it's going to be a slow day. Schedule them to work... Then tell them you don't need them! (Then wonder why people don't follow their schedule - ppl are always late, not showing up for shifts). It's Crazy.. The company is so obsessed with saving on labor that none of the hourly workers ever aspire to become managers because they see how abused the managers are. Since they are salaried, the managers are viewed by the company as mules... They are always pressured to send the hourly workers home (get them off the clock) and the managers end up having to take tables, bag to go orders, answer phones, seat guests, finish the prep work, etc. They work like dogs. Guests often stand at the door without being properly greeted because their is no host on the clock and everyone else is spread too thin around the restaurant. The company has a nice veneer, but its a corporation... No soul. It's all greed and profit-based once you get down to it. You feel suckered after working there a short while.
Advice to Management_y: Mandate a thirty minute meal break for managers. Have GMs limit the hours their managers work and stop using them as prep cooks, hosts and servers to save labor. My daily tasks include doing prep work that most other restaurants would have a cook do. Give managers leeway with labor. Most of my shifts have a10-15% labor margin! That's incredibly good, why are you still obsessed with cutting labor? Cut ME a break once and a while!

Pros_x: Working at Chili's is like working for any other chain restaurant. Menu is always changing as well as procedures. A lot of the restaurants are getting a new remodel which looks much better than the previous.
Cons_x: Disconnect between Corporate and the actual restaurants and depending which store you work at, customers can make or break your night.
Advice to Management_x: I never had an issue with management at the stores I worked at. There were always at least 3 managers in the restaurant and all were usually very different.

Title_x: "Really good money for just working Togo"
Pros_x: I get the hours I want and the shifts I want. I also have lots of regulars.
Cons_x: The cooks can be very difficult to work with, probably because they just don't care anymore. They don't read the tickets and make the food correct most of the time and when you ask them to put tickets on the boxes like they are supposed to or make the food correctly you get yelled at because it's your fault and never theirs. They need to have more printers on the line so when the food gets bumped the cooks can have a chit to put on the box that is easy access for them.

Title_x: "Depends On the Restaurant You Work At"
Pros_x: -Some amazing co-workers and one good manager out of the three. -Customers where amazing and I got tipped as a hostess from regulars since Servers are not required to tip hostesses out. -Good Food
Cons_x: -Moving up is difficult and I was promised only three months of being a hostess and then my manager six months later after me being a hostess told me he never had any intention of moving me up.. -Servers are not required to tip hostesses out, but hostesses where bullied into bussing servers tables since Chili's did away with busboys.. -Minimum wage pay, they don't always follow labor laws, worked several twelve hour shifts without a break.. -Short notice on meetings. Supposed to have monthly meetings and then we didn't- if we had a meeting we where not told until three or four days before and still required to show even if we had other obligations.. -High turn over rate.. I stayed for seven months and at the end of the seven months we had 4 hostesses that where hired and had already quit. The only same people that where there was the head chef, managers, a bartender, a server, and myself. They didn't train me until a month into me working on the floor, which made no sense.. -Time off is so hard to get- I am a college student who handed in my Christmas break and Spring Break days in when I was hired in August and told them I had to have those days off- the dorms would close so I had to go back home- told it would not be a problem and then I had to fight to get Christmas break off and I ended up quitting a week before Spring Break because after they said for the last two months it would not be a problem, they then scheduled me and when I told them I couldn't work they said oh well. I quit after that.. -They don't hire enough people. We had three hostesses including myself. Two could only work lunches and not weekends. I ended up working every single night and doubles/triples on Saturday and Sunday. I am full-time college and said I could not work more than 25 hours a week and they said that was fine when they hired me. After the first month my hours where 35 to 45 a week- when I said I needed them backed down to what we agreed on, they said no and that they couldn't since they didn't have enough people to work and couldn't hire anyone else.. -Got told I would have to drive to the other Chili's thirty minutes away during my break (when I got one) to pick up extra food but couldn't do it on the clock (in case I got into an accident-they didn't want it on their time) and never compensated for gas. Told it was part of my "job responsibilities.". . Chili's itself is an amazing company. I never got to see benefits and getting my shift meals where always hard. Older workers would bully the younger and newer ones. I had a girl pour a drink on me on purpose (a worker) and the manager didn't do anything about it so I smelled of alcohol the rest of my shift and then got in trouble for it. I have friends who worked at other Chili's and they love it and haven't had a problem. It depends on the MANAGEMENT. I ended up waiting 3 days in a row for over a hour and a half each day for an interview with each manager- that should've been my red flag.. . Also, Chili's does not drug test. That was a huge problem.
Advice to Management_x: Don't lie to your employees, treat them like they are valued. If there is a problem, don't tell them to just tell another crew member where to go and how to get there, help them solve it. Work with your employees. I had several regulars who loved me and got mad when I told them I was leaving, I was valued by customers but not by the staff and that was why I had to leave. I stayed so long because of the amazing customers. Be considerate, employees are people also.

Pros_x: Good flexible job if in school or for extra cash on the weekends. Can earn around $27/hour average if at a good-tipping location.
Cons_x: More and more duties delegated to less and less workforce. They're cutting labor, due to rising minimum wage. Cash can be very inconsistent.
Advice to Management_x: Focus on healthier fare, one of the fastest growing markets. Use less waste in food prep, such as stop cooking food in plastic bags.

Pros_x: Management works towards a positive culture, 50% discount to Brinker restaurants is good.
Cons_x: It is still a casual dining restaurant, automation has overtaken any sort of culinary skill in the BOH
Advice to Management_x: Keep weeding out the negative employees and boosting the positive ones
Pros_y: Great discount on food until you get tired of it. Pretty decent salary and okay quarterly bonuses if you hit your numbers.
Cons_y: Poor quality of life. Inconsistent scheduling and inconsistent scheduler. Upper management plays favorites and has no regard for the people below them. Major focus on productivity so constantly understaffed and managers get stuck working in a position instead of managing. Unhappy guests and team members make for a consistent negative work environment. Constant rollout a and never ending menu.
Advice to Management_y: Get rid of BRG focus and allow your managers to manage. Recognize their is a serious problem when you lose four Area Directors from the same region in a 6month time span.

Pros_x: It's a large company with plenty of assets. Sales were good and bonuses were usually just as good.
Cons_x: Bonus structure would change a couple of times a year. Big turnover in management. Fourteen out of fifteen GM's were fired or quit in 2011. The Directors usually lasted about 6 months.
Advice to Management_x: Be prepared for a backup plan, because they are not afraid it let you go without a justifiable cause.

Sounds fairly normal for employees to advance to higher ranks and different titles.. Awesome orientation process.. Looks fun, employees look like cool people, managers come off as people I'd enjoy working for.
Cons_x: I haven't worked a day to come up with a complaint as of yet. Only thing I could say is they had a couple problems finding my name in their system during hiring process. Advice to Management_x: Keep up the good work. Get larger tables, I can hardly fit in the non-booths.

Title_x: "Great People, Few Hours if not serving"
Pros_x: This is a restaurant job, but if you can find a good group of people and you're willing to help out wherever, it is a great place to be. The managers are fair and considerate and I felt appreciated more than I had expected.
Cons_x: If you don't serve, you won't get many hours. That's not anything that can be changed - that's just the business. The hourly is pretty decent, but if you just host, you MAYBE get 15 hours a week.
Advice to Management_x: Always stay positive with the people under you. Even if they screw up, if you attack them, they are very likely to hold a grudge and avoid doing work. Find people who are willing to help out wherever they're needed and you'll have a great team. And make sure to make relationships with your team members - it just makes life more fun!

Pros_x: It's a good mix of casual and professional. As far as the plate $$ range, you'll probably make more than at other comparable restaurants. Getting to wear jeans and often a t-shirt doesn't seem like much, but it makes work more comfortable. Music isn't as bad as at other restaurants. Food is genuinely good.
Cons_x: No breaks, they recently got sued for this and little changed. Except now you have to waive your right to the break when you clock out, or you don't get to clock out. Asking for a break is a joke as they do not employ breakers. Bus boys were also eliminated to save on labor hours. Gem scores were some of the most stressful and unfair aspects of any job I've ever had. I saw some of the best employees fired for things completely out of their control. This also leads to dishonesty as employees consistently cheat to avoid the bad scores.
Advice to Management_x: I know the ziosk machines were very expensive, but they aren't helping.

Cons_x: No vacations. No sick days. No family leave. Badly designed training system. A productivity rate that has tripled over the past few years. Chili's bases their front of the house schedules on a survey system that shoulders all the shortcomings of the restaurant squarely upon the servers. Expect apathy from the management with what I have dubbed, "The Management Shrug". There are more microwaves than cooks.
Advice to Management_x: Stop using surveys to separate yourselves from your guests and your staff. Get out of your offices and come and put on an apron and experience the work environment you have created.

Pros_x: +Meeting new people. +Trying new foods whenever we got new menus. +Discounts. +Making great friends who treat you like family. +I worked at a testing location so we were always the first to have the new menus and technology.. +you can 'move up' to other jobs like ToGo, QA,Server, etc. +If your location has the NoWait system your job is 10 times easier because it takes care of rotation for you,it has a built in waiting list, as well as tell you what tables are clean/dirty/occupied,.. . Chilis was founded in Dallas in 1975 so if you work at a Dallas location its pretty important that you are always on your best behavior because 'Brinkers' (the people who own Chili;s now) are always secretly checking in on you.
Cons_x: +Sometimes it can be a little hectic depending on your location. +A lot of the workers like to date and sometimes it gets a little messy.. +You might have to work on holidays
Advice to Management_x: Keep up the great work. There are always at least three managers around ready to help you whenever needed. And whenever we have a guest manager they instantly become part of the family and are ready to get to work. Honestly a great franchise to be apart of.

Advice to Management_x: A food runner, server assistant, rover and a busser at each shift would make shifts go smoother.. At least two 10 to 15-minute breaks would be really helpful.. I know that adding these four people per shift would increase labor, but you guys are killing us. My back and feet never hurt so much in all my life! We need breaks and we need to be able to efficiently share the load.

Pros_x: The menu changes slightly every season, making it harder for servers to become bored with their workplace. I never participated in their healthcare plan, but from what I read (I was offered enrollment) there are definitely some good/competitive healthcare benefits. Coworkers at my location (Wayne, PA) were by far the best part of the job. Even after leaving, I still keep in touch with almost all of them.
Cons_x: Perhaps it was just the location in particular, but management was extremely poor. The turnover rate for managers was high, and as a server it definitely kept you on your toes -- and not in a good way. Some of the managers developed negative attitudes towards working there (the second they started their shift you could tell they did not want to be there) and were insanely incompetent; many of them did not understand the idea of leaving their personal life behind prior to coming into work and displayed clear favoritism towards particular employees. I experienced several instances of sexual harassment on part of the kitchen staff, and even after bringing it up to a manager, said manager did nothing to remedy the situation or even attempt to inform the GM (I did not feel comfortable discussing the situation personally with the GM). From what I understand now after speaking to former coworkers at the location, it appears that management is being cleaned up by the regional director (who, by the way, is actually fantastic at his job and probably the only superior I miss), so hopefully things will improve in the future.
Advice to Management_x: Learn how to give clear direction and provide equal expectations (regardless of favoritism and/or personal relationships) to ALL employees. Take your job more seriously, and understand that subordinates will learn from your example. If you display a poor work ethic, you can expect your staff to lack any respect for you and your position, and the restaurant will continue to function in absolute chaos. Most importantly, never -- NEVER -- trash talk subordinates in front of other subordinates. It breeds distrust among employees and an uncomfortable working environment. Every manager at this location during my time there was guilty of such trash talk. It is highly unprofessional, notwithstanding immature.

Pros_x: Management cares about the business, Busy environment -- able to make a good amount of tips, Bar drinks are simple, Can turn tables in order to make more money, People make a living from the tips they earn from Chili's, The scheduling is well done, Large tables sections
Cons_x: The Ziosk system really seems to bring down good servers/bartenders. The customers are able to rate their service, but they also can rate the quality of food or the cleanliness of the restaurant. The scores directly impact the employee, which is not necessarily fair when some of the bad scores have nothing to do with the servers work. Some people allow their children to take the survey at the end and they just press buttons not realizing that it effects the employee.
Advice to Management_x: Stop putting so much emphasis on the Ziosk scores and focus more on training employees to be the best server/bartender they can be given that person's personality. The ziosk system should be updated to really give an idea of how the restaurant is doing as a whole rather then the individual server quality.

Pros_x: Had some great coworkers and managers. Fun environment, good food, 50% discount. THE SOFTBALL TOURNAMENT! I don't know about other states, but in Illinois, all Chili's get together and have one giant softball tournament. Being a softball player, this was the single greatest thing about working at Chili's. Flexible schedule, but required to work weekends--after you gain some seniority, there will most likely be some flexibility in this.
Cons_x: Had some bad coworkers and management, but they didn't last long. If you're looking to move up in the company, there aren't too many opportunities. Out of almost 10 years, I only saw a couple servers go into management, and it's not because people didn't want to or weren't qualified. None of my managers were ever servers at Chili's, they were all outside hires.

Pros_x: You walk away with $200+ in cash every weekend worked. Great way to communicate with others and to learn more about the restaurant business. A great opportunity for those who enjoy working with other people.
Cons_x: Poorly managed. Poor working environment (very hot and crammed). Hourly wages for servers are half of regular minimum wage (because we keep tips). Wages heavily rely on the generosity of others (tips). No minimum gratuity for large parties. Poor flexibility for scheduling, especially for weekends and holidays. Discrimination against other employees and customers (management enjoys making fun of others secretly).
Advice to Management_x: I enjoyed the work I performed but the conditions I performed my duties were far extremely poor. Not only did I hate going to work because of the way management treated me but it was also always very warm and crammed working conditions. Tips were usually awful (most people are very cheap and usually tip next to nothing). The working environment was just extremely pathetic. I always felt I was being made fun of and when I tried to report this to upper management, absolutely nothing was done. So, I quit. And I have not regretted quitting one bit. Perhaps the worst working experience I have ever had. Chili's is just an awful company to work for - considering they don't care one bit about their employees or customers. But, wait.. What do they care about? Oh yeah; money. As usual.

Pros_x: No mental strain. MGMT doesn't care if you eat or take food home, no uniform or personal upkeep needed,
Cons_x: Terrible training, dumb mgmt, blatant favoritism over work ethic/ability in promotions, zero foresight on business volume leading to dramatic over or under staffing, disgustingly dirty kitchen, repeatedly ignorant mistakes from FOH from evident under training
Advice to Management_x: Replace all your upper and middle mgmt in Western NC, loosen rigidity in mgmt styles, mimic mgmt training of top companies like Google, smoke your ribs longer, pay real cooks higher wages, and microwave less

Pros_x: Better then most restaurant companies - They understand that a manager needs a life outside of work.
Cons_x: They compensate GM's well, but not assistant managers. They need a more balance approach to retain their teams.
Advice to Management_x: Buy out the franchise communities that are not growing your brand.
Pros_y: Better then most restaurant companies - They understand that a manager needs a life outside of work.
Cons_y: They compensate GM's well, but not assistant managers. They need a more balance approach to retain their teams.
Advice to Management_y: Buy out the franchise communities that are not growing your brand.

Pros_x: Chili's has a great training program it includes front of the house and back of the house and it is always on-going. GM I work for does a great job balancing the schedule and working with your needs.
Cons_x: Labor in almost any company is always an issue. I feel we cut too much labor in the back of the house which makes execution difficult. This means management must wear many different hats including prep, line cook and jumping in dish. Also, because labor is so tight sometimes morale is low in the BOH because of the high expectation of each employee.
Advice to Management_x: Understanding labor is your biggest controllable especially for a large corporation but it comes a point where cutting too much labor will effect your guest because execution becomes nearly impossible given the tasks at hand. Give some money back to the restaurants for labor so BOH actually enjoy their jobs and have passion and drive to do the best job for our guests.

Pros_x: 9 days off a month, extra days on month of your birthday and anniv. Good work life balance for comparable companies/positions.

Pros_x: They have a good bonus program that is attainable for the managers. All managers are responsible for all orders liquor,food,small wares.
Cons_x: The manager schedules are never consistent and have you bouncing all over and very rarely do you ever get two days off in a row. Day off work then day off makes no sense to not give you two days in a row off.
Advice to Management_x: Give more two days in a row off instead of day off wok day off. Unless of a holiday or special event there should be no problem with two in a row if family first is your company standard.

Pros_y: They have a good bonus program that is attainable for the managers. All managers are responsible for all orders liquor,food,small wares.
Cons_y: The manager schedules are never consistent and have you bouncing all over and very rarely do you ever get two days off in a row. Day off work then day off makes no sense to not give you two days in a row off.
Advice to Management_y: Give more two days in a row off instead of day off wok day off. Unless of a holiday or special event there should be no problem with two in a row if family first is your company standard.

Pros_x: - Funny group of coworkers. - Relaxed management. - Fun job. - Family atmosphere. - There are a lot of corporate promotions within the store for prizes or bonuses. These were really good at incentivizing the team to boost sales
Cons_x: - Not much money for waiters. - Incompetent coworkers (hostess especially). Management was also a mixed bag, and made different shifts vastly different.
Advice to Management_x: do not put so much emphasis on holidays (i.e. don't overstaff on those days) People aren't coming to party at chili's for cinco de mayo so let your employees take the time off to have some fun.

Pros_x: Flexible shifts. Ability to pick up shifts using Hot Schedules. Good money. They give to charity every year
Cons_x: A lot of the managers play favorites. They are not understanding and usually take sides. I did not like that we had to work in teams. If you were stuck working with someone that you did not work well with, they would bring you down. A lot of the servers are mean and not accepting of new comers.
Advice to Management_x: Work on the getting to know your employees better and not rely on hear say from other employees. Stop playing favorites, it does not make employees feel comfortable. Positive critiques are encouraged. When you only focus on something that someone does wrong and never praise them for things that they are doing right, they will not feel valued as employees.

Cons_x: Unpredictable work schedule, cut from the floor early due to "slow days". Only $2.13 hrly not including tips.
Advice to Management_x: Continue being supportive. Schedule according to expected volume so some servers don't get cut from the floor with a couple of hrs of being at work. Pros_x: If you love a fast paced, non -stop busy environment this is the place for you. The pay is competitive, you get the tools you need, the people I worked with were awesome.
Cons_x: Upper Management is only concerned with their bonus and how much more they can get on the backs of the people who work very hard in the restaurant. if you can not get them the bonus they want you are fired.
Advice to Management_x: People will work harder for the company if the company took care of the people; but show it not just talk it.

Pros_x: Flexible schedule, walking out with cash, relating with customers and growing them into regulars, growth opportunities within the company, and a laidback approach to casual dining.
Cons_x: Working weekends is mandatory, constant changes to both the food and drink menus, never ending push to sell more products, bare-bone work crews to cut down cost for the company to bring in more revenue.

Pros_x: The TM's are very nice to work with. The pay was nice considering it was a very easy job as a manager.
Cons_x: To ever be promoted to a GM it is all about who you know rather than your work skills.
Advice to Management_x: Pay attention to ACTUAL numbers managers produce and the MEE comments from TM's about other managers. Could eliminate the turnover.

Pros_x: Super flexible. Transfered to four different locations. Got me through college. Excellent coworkers and life long friends. A truly fun work environment.
Cons_x: Snotty customers but thats everywhere.
Pros_y: comp card for anywhere and 50% off magginos. 40-50 hr work week. GM was fair with schedule no pre employment drug test. great health insurance. offer part time manger after full time 80 % salary for 4 day week, if 60% you get 3 day work week, so start with a good base,
Cons_y: had to take home work to do elearning at home..you get paid but sill after a 10 hr shift. GM was not hands on with training you were free to walk around and long as you were busy with something,. horrible kitchen shifts... you get stuck back there with team members, one of my trainer had only been there 3 weeks, she was very immature and didnt want any questions while busy,. make you do portion and weigh food to be kept for sale for 5 hrs a day at times.but if you walked away from it to help others you were in trouble for it.. but only later would be told, on hands training is always busy shifts on weekends where the emoloyee traniner couldnt train you in a proper manner. they read the test to you and tel you the test answers,. gm spend alot of time in the office ..thought he
Advice to Management_y: Get more hands on, teach your students and be a better mentor. get ou

Employee Title_x: Food Server, Food Expeditor, Host, Busser
Pros_x: If you work full-time they allow you to opt in for benefits such as 401k, vision, health, and dental. Friendly managers and co-workers. Very flexible with schedules for those going to school, have two jobs, etc.
Cons_x: Constantly run out of things. Benefits not available to part-time workers. Lack of communication across the restaurant sometimes causing quality of service towards guests to drop down.
Advice to Management_x: All managers are great. Just step up your game and consistently make sure everyone is doing their job as they should be. Ensure staff is on their A-game as well and work a bit on inventory as far as projected sales, etc.

GM was not hands on with training you were free to walk around and long as you were busy with something,. horrible kitchen shifts... you get stuck back there with team members, one of my trainer had only been there 3 weeks, she was very immature and didnt want any questions while busy,. make you do portion and weigh food to be kept for sale for 5 hrs a day at times.but if you walked away from it to help others you were in trouble for it.. but only later would be told, on hands training is always busy shifts on weekends where the emoloyee traniner couldnt train you in a proper manner. they read the test to you and tel you the test answers,. gm spend alot of time in the office ..thought he
Advice to Management_y: Get more hands on, teach your students and be a better mentor. get ou

Pros_x: Really great co-workers, helpful assistant managers. It is a fun, fast-paced environment with good enough training provided.
Cons_x: Shifts are less based on merit; factors and numbers used to evaluate employees are skewed. Menu items change so constantly, that many regulars are lost. The General Manager is involved in operations, but does not show he has any care for the well-being and development of any individual employee.
Advice to Management_x: Make more of an attempt to gain feedback from employees, it may boost their morale towards management and help the company with turnover. Hiring too many employees to do the same job leads to too few of shifts for employees, causing disgruntled workers.

Pros_x: I've been with Chilis for about a year in a half and one of the best things I've come to love about being a server is all of the different types of individuals you get to surround yourself by. I don't know if its for this particular Chilis but I choose to believe that its not. I've grown to love the servers I'm around. You also learn valuable skills like memorization, multitasking, confidence in the way you talk and handle yourself around others, etc. The tips aren't bad either.
Cons_x: The feedback that customers leave on the ziosk can be a real downer especially when you start working for a company that has those to track your work/ progress as a server. There always that one customer who's decided to come into Chilis, when having a bad day, and he/she decides to take their day out on you.

Pros_x: The only pros are some of your coworkers, if they're professional enough to get along with. However, most aren't.
Cons_x: No complaints by any employee are taken seriously, ever. Coworkers literally scream and cuss each other out in the kitchen with no consequences, there is constant sexual harassment by the cooks that is swept under the rug, no team morale, no help from managers at all. All the managers care about are making it through the shift until their off days or next vacation. When the managers do actually handle a situation, it's incredibly unprofessional. They are known to cuss, name call, and basically make employees feel as though they're a complete nuisance to them. The worst and most unprofessional place I've ever worked. No bussers or food runners, and you can't count on help from anyone
Advice to Management_x: Actually help out your employees. Don't treat them like they're annoying just because they're busy, and solve the real issues within the restaurant instead of just making everyone get along for the time being. Don't turn female employees away when they come to you with a sexual harassment complaint just because you don't think it was that serious. Back up your employees in kitchen disputes and address issues with employees in a professional manner.
Pros_y: Great people. Religious values. Lots of training
Cons_y: Too much micromanaging. Lots of lists
Advice to Management_y: Less micromanaging

All the managers care about are making it through the shift until their off days or next vacation. When the managers do actually handle a situation, it's incredibly unprofessional. They are known to cuss, name call, and basically make employees feel as though they're a complete nuisance to them. The worst and most unprofessional place I've ever worked. No bussers or food runners, and you can't count on help from anyone
Advice to Management_x: Actually help out your employees. Don't treat them like they're annoying just because they're busy, and solve the real issues within the restaurant instead of just making everyone get along for the time being. Don't turn female employees away when they come to you with a sexual harassment complaint just because you don't think it was that serious. Back up your employees in kitchen disputes and address issues with employees in a professional manner.
Pros_y: Great people. Religious values. Lots of training
Cons_y: Too much micromanaging. Lots of lists
Advice to Management_y: Less micromanaging

Cons_x: they have a machine called the ziosk, which is a terrible invention. I was the hardest working waiter they had and most tables were very pleased with my service. I was fired solely based upon my ziosk score because I got all 4 out of 5 on every table. I would never work at a restaurant like this again or recommend them to a friend.
Advice to Management_x: Your GM and local restaurant managers need understand that the ziosk is only 1 small tool to judge a waiter ability; and understand that there are many different factors that will show weather a waiter is good or not.
