Cons_x: Upper management are hostile and abusive. Threatening you with your job whenever they can. Long hours and understaffed. Only hear from AD when it is bad feedback. Little to no recognition. Unorganized business structure. Upper management do not know much about operations or have seemed to have forgot.
Advice to Management_x: Study your cultural beliefs. If you can't follow them or live them, how do you expect anyone to. Stop with the flip flopping leadership style. Support your team not belittle and tear them down.

Title_x: "Corporate Management Is Ruining It For Everyone"
Pros_x: As far as the actual tasks required of you in the kitchen, it is one of the easiest jobs you could have in the industry. Everything you have to make is on posters with step by step guidelines on how to prepare it, everything has a timer associated with it, and ninety nine percent of the food just goes through a conveyor belt oven on the same plate its served on. hours and pay are the same as any other corporate restaurant chain.
Cons_x: Because they are a publicly traded stock, Brinker's (Chili's) corporate higher-ups constantly rollout more and more ways to save time and labor in the kitchen and front of house. I can't call them evil or cruel for doing this, its simply in the best interest of the company's growth. Unfortunately, the ones who pay the price are the ones at the bottom of the ladder, the cooks and the servers. While it sounds great and easy getting all your food already prepared and ready to eat, that means less labor hours for us back of house guys and girls. Over five years of working at Chili's I saw this firsthand. I watched a lot of talented people leave the company because they saw that the company was moving away from talent.
Advice to Management_x: Chili's, treat the little people who keep your restaurant running a little better. happy employees and a hardworking team can do a lot more than fancy ovens and frozen food.
Pros_y: Decent pay and bonus structure. Great team members who truly care about the business and it's success. Good cultural practices. Great community involvement.
Cons_y: Upper management are hostile and abusive. Threatening you with your job whenever they can. Long hours and understaffed. Only hear from AD when it is bad feedback. Little to no recognition. Unorganized business structure. Upper management do not know much about operations or have seemed to have forgot.
Advice to Management_y: Study your cultural beliefs. If you can't follow them or live them, how do you expect anyone to. Stop with the flip flopping leadership style. Support your team not belittle and tear them down.

Title_x: "Overall experience depends on the market in which you work and, further, the Area Director (AD) you work under."
Pros_x: Amazing pay! Always have others to help you; Benefits are great--at least for someone like myself--single/no dependents. Conveniently located throughout the world so transferring (if needed) is usually not a problem unless you happen to be on bad terms of course! Menu is a favorite amongst all generations--attracting a LARGE and diverse crowd. While presentation and quality are the focus of Chili's food, the general feel is 'Laid Back' and comfortably casual. In short, this is the PERFECT beginning to anyone's career in restaurant management. Would I suggest it for someone looking to settle into a long-term restaurant management career? Absolutely not. A first timer? ABSOLUTELY.
Cons_x: Hours are TERRIBLE 60+hrs/weekly; Never able to set yourself on a schedule due to the differing shifts/hours worked week to week

Pros_x: They had updated ziosks which helped take off some of the load of serving. Customers could check themselves out or add on to their bill. They also had online service for the schedule so that it was easy to access.
Cons_x: Although there were many managers, the schedule didn't come out until the day before the week started. Even with that they would change it online midweek then wonder why people didn't show up to work. They had "team service" which they would purposefully pair a lesser server with a better one which ended up being the better server had to handle their section and pick up slack for the other server. The sections they made up were poorly planned out on top of that making one section made up of six six-tops that on days like sunday would be totally full.
Advice to Management_x: Be more organized. Make the schedule two at a time. You can't expect much from your staff when you yourself are not doing your job to the fullest. Putting the schedule out late basically tells your staff that their time means nothing. They just have to work whenever you say.
Pros_y: People First Company with emphasis on development.
Cons_y: The industry requires nights and weekends.

Pros_x: half off food and friendly people
Cons_x: overwhelming if you are not customer service savy
Pros_y: People First Company with emphasis on development.
Cons_y: The industry requires nights and weekends.

Pros_x: I get to listen to my own music as long as I can hear everyone else and enjoy the other cooks attitudes
Cons_x: Some of the servers don't care about my organized table and will out plates anywhere they want to
Advice to Management_x: Let the servers know that the dishwashers like to keep their table organized
Pros_y: People First Company with emphasis on development.
Cons_y: The industry requires nights and weekends.

Pros_x: Casual Dining at it's finest, it's pretty easy to get the hang of it and start making some money. Fast-paced environment where time flies by during the busier hours. After 6 months, you get a 50% discount card available for all Brinker positions. It's often easy to get a shift covered or pick up an extra one.
Cons_x: In a place so socially connected, drama is quick to sprout up at any moment. It is a high-stress position and requires someone who can keep their cool during the rush.
Advice to Management_x: Set up contests or fun activities that joins Front of House/Heart of House. The disconnect between the two can become hostile, so it's important to keep up the morale of both sides of the QA line. I suggest a game with the following: Pairing up each FoH member with a HoH member, and setting up individual goals for them to reach to gain points that fits their job discription. Ex. Have a FoH member sell a particular item on the menu that the HoH is in charge of making and if it is made to the QA's specifications, that team gets a point. Give chili's gear as prizes, or go to a dollar store and bring in some candy, something to motivate your workforce. Activities like this breaks up the monotony, strengthens the bond between FoH/HoH, and lowers the hostility that can occur during the stress hours.
Pros_y: People First Company with emphasis on development.
Cons_y: The industry requires nights and weekends.

Pros_x: Fast paced and tips depend directly on how hard you work.
Cons_x: Location of restaurant hinders business due to it being a tourist destination. Leads to unsteady income.
Pros_y: People First Company with emphasis on development.
Cons_y: The industry requires nights and weekends.

Pros_x: Chili's was a great place to be a server, because it is well known and there were always customers. Management seemed bitter, but that is common in most restaurants.
Cons_x: Because of the price range, some of the clientele did not tip well. There is a clear line between FOH and BOH staff and oftentimes that makes it difficult for servers to work.
Advice to Management_x: Let servers do what they do best. They are the face of the company and should be kept happy.

Pros_x: I made good money and the other people working there were pleasant and helpful for the most part. Some of the managers were also helpful.
Cons_x: Always understaffed and ill equipped to handle the volume of guests. Upper management continued to set goals that were completely off basis to how the restaurant was run. For example servers could get fired or demoted based off the survey's that were on the ziosks. Even though it was a small amount of people who took the survey and a small amount of people who payed through the ziosk. This is completely whack according to the scientific method.
Advice to Management_x: Actually be in tune to what is happening on the company. Also don't always put the blame on the servers. sERVING AT CHILIS IS THE WORST BECAUSE YOU HAVE NO RUNNERS OR BUSSERS YOU DO IT ALL ON YOUR OWN.There is no one refilling ice in the back, there's no one make desserts or soup, there's no one wiping your tables.

Cons_x: The company took away paid vacation time from the full-time employee base. They did this when times were tough and never gave it back. They will often try to put things as though they are helping you when they are really hurting.

Pros_x: Leaving at the end of my shift is the one and only highlight of the day. The only other pros are my days off. Sign up for the 401k so that you have money for when you quit. You'll be glad you did.
Cons_x: Low pay. Idiotic and extremely lazy coworkers. Extremely lazy management. NO paid vacation for full time hourly employees. Instead of a paid vacation you get a lousy $250 yearly bonus which is about $160 after taxes.
Advice to Management_x: Employees are human beings. Treat them as such. Everyone knows the reason people go into management is so they can make more money and do less work but at least try not to make it so obvious. Lead by example.

Pros_x: Great pay and benefits. But you pay the price with integrity
Cons_x: Company does not follow its own rules and policies. Poor leadership and inconsistant management create work environment. Constant turnover of employees because of poor treatment.
Advice to Management_x: Start running the operation with integrity. Dont have rules and policies on the books that you have no intention of following or enforcing. Be open to new ideas and change.

Title_x: "A great place to start off. Former Server"
Pros_x: The employees and the managers are very kind and understanding. You really feel like you're part of a big family. The pay varies, but you can make a decent amount of money here if you're young and just starting out. The customers usually tip well, and have a positive attitude for the most part.
Cons_x: The pay isn't consistent. There are very dry days, sometimes dry weeks. So a second job may be mandatory. The customers can be cruel depending on location, and management doesn't really do much to assist you in those situations. Co workers can do some pretty unsavory things to get more money than you, since it is a competitive job. Hours aren't consistent, and the high turnover rate does affect the work load.

Pros_x: Working at Chili's Grill & Bar it's fun and it is a pretty relaxed environment to work in. It is a casual dining restaurant so it is not overly stressful.
Cons_x: THEY ARE VERY FOCUSED ON THE SCORES THEY RECEIVE FROM CUSTOMER WHO FILL OUT SURVEYS ON THE ZIOSK AND THEY HAVE FOOD SELLING COMPETITIONS YOU MUST COMPETE IN.
Advice to Management_x: Be more friendly to your staff we will be more motivated to work hard when you are nice, fun, and cool with us; compared to if you yell at us to do something that'll just make us not want to do it. Treat us as your equals and we will work hard and be grateful.

Pros_x: The servers that have been there make it worth working there and make you want to come back. They are the ones who support you through your shifts. Great bartenders and cook staff as well. You can get good hours and full benefits.
Cons_x: The GM doesn't have the employees backs. Many employees don't show up or come in late with no repercussions. Diners don't tip well regardless of how well you serve, and on a weekend night, you're lucky to make a bill. You're often stuck rolling silverware and doing work for the closers while only making the $2.13 an hour while not on the floor. There is a high turnover rate at this location.

Advice to Management_x: be leaders not micromanagers. In the food service industry there is nothing less helpful than a manager with empty hands saying "full hands out of dish" especially knowing not a single thing about what we are doing in the moment. If you do not want to participate in the servers job title anymore than do not manage in food service. You should still feel the need to take on the same duties as servers as a manager if the servers need help. STOP THE MICROMANAGEMENT!!

Pros_x: Great Co workers. On some nights you make really great money. Flexible. Real team effort by everybody. Plenty of opportunity to work your way up.
Cons_x: Sometimes its slow and our General Manager has driven several employees out of working due to her poor attitude and constant negativity. Then, when she is told this, the positivity comes out so forced that everybody knows she is only saying whats needed to be said if anything were to threaten her job.

Pros_x: Great team, excellent leadership and integrity. Solid training provided with plenty of room for growth. Adequate resources to get the expected results. There are high expectations but the goals are reasonable and achievable
Cons_x: Like most restaurant jobs there can be long hours and closing shifts can keep you till 1 or 2 in the morning.
Advice to Management_x: I feel the leadership team has not only the interest of the business and profitability in mind but also genuinely care about the welfare of their managers and the chiliheads. Keep that philosophy as happy employees make for profitable restaurants

Pros_x: Meet good friends, some management is ok
Cons_x: Focus too much on ziosk scores and not enough on actual server ability and skill. Punishes by cutting much needed hours and shifts down to next to nothing. "Promotes" unfairly to not so deserving employees while casting aside those who do deserve. Favoritism very much a factor.
Advice to Management_x: Focus more on server ability and work ethic. Look at scores as a whole, and recognize the issues and understand that more often than not its a food quality, or restaurant itself issue and not the server themselves.

Title_x: "Have not received a raise in 2 years"
Pros_x: Great benefits, but only if your restaurant allows you to keep your hours above 32 a pay period. In some places this isn't possible. For servers not trying to support a family it's a great place to work. For everyone else it's not.
Cons_x: The food quality is horrible, the restaurants are all dirty once you make it to the kitchen, there isn't any cohesion between management (after all I have seen three entire management staffing changes in the 3 years I've been there), and after learning every position in the back of the house I still haven't received the raise I was promised. This may have to do with the 56.5 million dollar class action lawsuit that the company was hit with, that they decided to shove the loss down our throats.
Advice to Management_x: Don't promise someone something you cant deliver on, and if you make a mistake in corporate decision making, don't dock us positions and wage increases because of your mistake.

Pros_x: fun atmosphere. laid back. set your own pay
Cons_x: wait on people. favoritism. seniority. no room for growth
Pros_y: Had great atmosphere and many opportunities for income growth! Benefits were great and leadership was very understanding.
Cons_y: You have to be very disciplined and driven to take the opportunities and something from nothing. Have to be willing to dedicate a lot of hours upfront so having a family is challenging.
Advice to Management_y: Important to focus on the people aspect CONSISTENTLY to continue to excel forward. Culture and outlook is great but size can be a limiting factor to growth opportunities.

Title_x: "Fine tune your basic service skills into crafting a more personalized dinning experience for your guests."
Pros_x: The training is top notch! Various "modules" are geared towards supplying you with the tools you will need to make MORE money and create an all around better dinning experience for your guests! Good work ethic is NOT overlooked here at Chilis... Work your butt off every day and you will see doors open and better opportunities arise.
Cons_x: Chilis hires at an entry level for service positions. Sometimes it becomes a bit of a pain to sort through the hacks that just don't cut it out on the floor.
Advice to Management_x: Utilize the awesome training better! Help the trainers identify the true gems hidden in the extremely large and extremely intimidating Training Binder.

Pros_x: Good use of technology like Hot Schedules to pick up and give away shifts. Easy to work with schedule wise. Never had a problem with Managers working with me to help cover a shift.
Cons_x: WAY TOO MUCH SIDE WORK. Side work averages 30 - 45 minutes to complete. Other restaurants might have 5 minutes of side work. Shifts are way too long as well. If you're in a closing section you'll be there for 7-8 hours versus other restaurants being 4-6 . Clientele is average too 6- 8 buck tips are as good as it gets.
Pros_y: great customers, great employees, would of loved to stay but relocated to a different area. It was a fun loving place, especially all of the local customers.
Cons_y: No cons what so ever! I would love to own my own Chilis because when management is not paying attention, things start to get out of hand.

Pros_x: Fun & Exciting Environment. You Get To Enjoy & Have A Good Time With The Customer's.
Cons_x: A Lot of Customer's Know How To Get Free Items And The Manager's Allow It, Even Though They Know The Customer Is Lying About Something On Their Order Being Incorrect Or Saying Their Food/Drinks Took Too Long. Also, The Manager's Aren't Always Kind/Thankful To The Staff.
Advice to Management_x: Listen To Your Employee's, They Are The One's Out On The Floor And Even The Back of The House Employee's As Well. Take Constructive Criticism From All The Employee's To Make The Work Environment Fun & Exciting So The Staff Wants To Go To Work Every Shift.
Pros_y: great customers, great employees, would of loved to stay but relocated to a different area. It was a fun loving place, especially all of the local customers.
Cons_y: No cons what so ever! I would love to own my own Chilis because when management is not paying attention, things start to get out of hand.

Pros_x: Team members who are bought in to the old chilihead way create a great atmosphere. the schedule can be flexible to fit your needs.
Cons_x: Freeze on wages for all hourly employees for over 3 years. No reviews or raises in 4 years. Do not count on years on the job, performance or willingness to work making a difference in your schedule. What you make on your hire date will probably be the same wage you make in 4 years no matter what you do.
Advice to Management_x: Please take care of the people who take care of you. Just because someone is willing to do whatever it takes does not mean they deserve to get less.

Pros_x: Great place to make friends, and to learn the do's and don't's of customer service. If you can take a lot of tables, the pay is also decent.
Cons_x: Management doesn't care, and that attitude is also reflected upon the other employees. You must work late nights and weekends in order to make great money. The employees are also scored daily by customers with questions that have nothing to do with the servers service. These scores can determine how many tables a server is permitted to have. For example, one question the survey asks customers to rate the quality of food.
Advice to Management_x: Listen to the suggestions of employees. Make them feel valued, and at the very least attempt to make it look like you actually care. If you don't, then neither will anyone else....

Title_x: "Other Places Do The Same Thing Better"
Pros_x: Flexible Schedule. Lots of opportunity to advance
Cons_x: Unreliable Hours. No Quality Benefits. Too much sidework. Unhappy Environment. Terrible Management. Managers Pick Favorites. High Turnover Rate. Too Many Doubles. NO TEAMWORK. Horribly disorganized
Advice to Management_x: Everything about the way you run your business is a joke. Give incentives for people to stay employeed at your company long term. Increasing your bottom line will actually increase your top line way more then you think. Having more servers on a night will allow those servers to give BETTER service bringing more business. Instead of 1 person doing a job for 3 people, have 3 people do the job of 1 person so that the 3 people can do the job better. It's impossible to give service that will make people want to come back for more if the server has 8 tables at once and has to cut corners because the kitchen is taking 45 minutes on appetizers. If you want more advice you can email me. Always happy to help.
Pros_y: Some great people to work with.
Cons_y: Unrealistic labor goal expectations. Too may initiatives/changes multiple times/year.
Advice to Management_y: Support your staff. Hopefully they were put into the position because they are capable. If not, then replace.

Pros_x: Working with a group of people that become like family. It is a great way to make extra cash when in the right location.
Cons_x: Horrible atmosphere when you have a GM that is only interested in numbers and stats. The balance and smoothness all depends on who's in charge at that location. Corporate has a lot of "quotas" to meet that are ridiculous for employees. For example, if you do not get a specific amount of customers to take the survey on their receipt, you get threatened of being demoted to "to go" or "hosting." Ridiculous that Corporate would hurt an employee based on what a paying customer decides to do once they leave the restaurant. Corporate is all about the numbers. Stick with a Chili's that has been franchised. Less greed.
Advice to Management_x: Corporate Chili's - stop basing your promotions on who sells the most margaritas and gets the most surveys because it is not fair when someone works 2 days vs someone who works 5. Common sense, less shifts, less margaritas. I should know, I was that person who worked 5.

Pros_x: Great benefits (if they work you full-time for at least a year,) friendly co-workers, discounted employee meals (an hour before shift,) great pay, and uses a helpful tool called HotSchedules for scheduling, which allows you to check you schedule, talk with other workers to pick up or drop schedules.
Cons_x: They're so overstaffed that there are about 12 people in the host position, and at least ten managers. Since they were so overstaffed in the host position, they only scheduled me for, on average, 5 hours a day, and maybe two or three times a week if lucky. There are so many managers that none of them are on the same page. They had said they were going to fire me, but never had, though they thought they did. When I called to ask about scheduling it took them 40 minutes to finally get a manager on the phone, and even then they refused to talk to me. I had to call back in a few days, and waited about 30 minutes for them to not answer my question, and tell me I was supposedly fired. It took me 3 weeks to get a paycheck that one manager said should've been given to me about a week prior, that another manager said hadn't even came in yet.
Advice to Management_x: You might want to start answering phone calls, and get all of the managers on the same page.

Pros_x: Flexible schedules, above average wages, team Service oriented, feels like every employee is part of the family.
Cons_x: Tips suck. I worked at 2 different locations and each one had it's own draw backs. One was busy but the kitchen staff was not up to par so every shift there was a disaster. Which in turn depletes tips. The other was slow with an awesome bog. But no guests no tips.
Advice to Management_x: Quit relying on those surveys so much. People are always negative and never satisfied. You put to much emphasis on those scores rather than being involved and seeing what servers are actually doing

Pros_x: You make good money for the most part.. On a really really good night you can make anywhere from 150-200. You get six table sections. I absolutely loved 2 of my managers, they were wonderful. There was another manager who was new, he was previously a server but he was another one that I loved, those 3 really really cared about me and I loved them too.
Cons_x: Where do I start..... It depends on who's working in the kitchen to how your food comes out, if we had the wrong staff in the kitchen, my food would come out all messed up then I would look bad because 2 out of the 3 people sitting at my table's food came out incorrectly.. Too much running sidework, it wouldn't be such a big deal if we didn't have so many lazy people working because we don't schedule people based on the amount of side work they do, we schedule them based on their scores so the people with the highest scores get to stand around on their phone and not worry about side work or running food so it's always the same 3 people doing side work and running food and they never get called out for not doing anything because their ziosk scores are high, it's really ridiculous. And the people who are doing everything don't get noticed for it because their scores aren't high enough and their scores won't go up because their too busy doing all the side work for the people who's scores are high so it's just a ridiculous pattern.. And the hosts, not to mention the hosts... They don't check on the servers because they don't care if we're weeded, we have 6 table sections so if you get 6 tables at once, it's almost impossible to greet and make drinks for 6 tables at once so you pretty much just break down. And the managers don't say anything about the hosts doing this to us because as long as there's not a wait at the door, that's all that matters, it doesn't matter if they get horrible service or if their food takes 30-45 minutes to come out, as long as they're not standing at the door waiting, that's all that matters. Most of the time, the managers are helping the hosts sit us 6 times in a row then wonder why we're drowning.. We're a team based restaurant so we have a partner in the floor which is sometimes good but most of the time bad because if you have a partner like me who works hard, it gives you as my partner an excuse to go stare at the kitchen for your food and ask me to do a bunch of stuff for your tables or for you to go to the bathroom or smoke while I watch your tables.. We close an hour later than any other restaurant so the last hour, we get crapped on.. We also do a bunch of cheap cheap deals so we get all the bad tips. The average check is 20$ so 15% of 20$ does not add up to much at the end of the night, you wind up doing more work for less money so a 6 table section doesn't really make a difference.. The 3 managers that I talked about in the pros were awesome but there was one who constantly yelled at us and talked disrespectful to the people he didn't wanna screw or didn't hang out with. He was also the one that made the schedule so only his favorites got a good schedule, like this one girl who wasn't even a very good server and I constantly had to cover her butt because she couldn't handle more than 2 tables but because he wanted to screw her she got the schedule she wanted. I heard him constantly talk about screwing her. There was one time every body could hear this particular manager yelling all the way at the front of the restaurant at an employee, it was really unprofessional and he doesn't deserve to be a manager.
Advice to Management_x: Pay better attention to your servers who are doing all the side work, stop only paying attention to a score that doesn't make any difference. The score has nothing to do with your server, it's not based on attentivness, it's based on whether or not they wanna return to a restaurant that may or may not have been dirty or a restaurant that their food might have taken 40 minutes or maybe their food was sent out with something their server 86'd but because I didn't run their food, I didnt see that it had something it wasn't suppose to on it or they had a kid in the next booth screaming in their ears or base it on the fact that they couldn't get sat in a booth instead of a table or that the bartender took a year and a day to make their drinks or maybe the host just sat me with 5 other tables and I really just couldn't control the service I have them.. Not everything is based off of a score that doesn't mean anything about my serving ability. Pay more attention to who actually cares and who actually is a good server but is just stuck covering everybody else's butts and doing the work for them. Pay better attention to what is really going on and not just what YOU wanna think is going on because 9 times out of 10, you're wrong.

Pros_x: Coworkers seemed to be very respectful. Restaurant was clean and training was good. Kitchen did a very good job.
Cons_x: Management allowed one complaint by a customer (who complained in the past in order to get free food) to be used in my termination. The customer was sat in a section that was not mine, I was not aware that this customer was to be waited on by me until she had been there almost 20 minutes. I did everything in my power to make her happy but she emailed the corporate office and got me fired!
Advice to Management_x: I understand that the hospitality business is all about pleasing the customer. With this being said, I do not believe that I should have lost my job due to one complaint that was from someone just trying to get a free meal.

Pros_x: Chili's is a great company to work for and a has a sincere leadership team who leads by example. Strong culture throughout the company which focuses on our team member experience as the key which unlocks our doors to success.
Cons_x: Food and Beverage is a competitive industry. Especially so in the casual dining / Bar & Grill segment which Chili's lives in. Although I believe our leadership will continue to guide us towards our goal of sustainable success and relevance, the sector itself is headed toward challenging and turbulent times.
Advice to Management_x: The size of you work week and quality of work life will be impacted by the location of your restaurant. Try to get placed in a bedroom community location (streets empty by 9pm). Your expected measurable results will be easier to achieve and you will work fewer hours.

Although I believe our leadership will continue to guide us towards our goal of sustainable success and relevance, the sector itself is headed toward challenging and turbulent times.
Advice to Management_y: The size of you work week and quality of work life will be impacted by the location of your restaurant. Try to get placed in a bedroom community location (streets empty by 9pm). Your expected measurable results will be easier to achieve and you will work fewer hours.

Pros_x: A great company to work for in my experience so far they treat their employees like family and always planning things to do outside of work
Cons_x: It is a fast environment and things can get busy really quick really fast
Advice to Management_x: I really have no advice to give to my managers at this point in my Chillies career maybe at some point in the new future

Pros_x: Servers are very friendly, they ACTUALLY have good on the job training and make sure you have all the tools needed to succeed on the job. very flexible and understanding team of people
Cons_x: you cant help it if you get a bad boss. or creepy co-workers sometimes.. . the pay is NOT worth the job. i was doing 3 times what any hostess at any other job would do and getting paid less.. there is no tipshare, yet i was doing half of the servers jobs, cleaning tables and helping customers get situated. it was too much for too little pay.
Advice to Management_x: be fair on pay.. you should not have to do someone else's job or be taken advantage of

Pros_x: It's a paycheck. Nothing more. Every day I loathe going into this place. Only bright side is getting in my car and leaving.
Cons_x: Ridiculously long hours, ineffective, incompetent, untrustworthy management, filthy work environment, apathetic, lazy, lowlife employees who are only there to pay child support and keep a bag of weed in their pocket, low pay for the work involved, no paid vacation time, anniversary bonuses ($250 per year for years 1-5, about $150 after taxes) in place of paid vacations are an insult, no incentives for doing a good job and going above and beyond.
Advice to Management_x: Quit. Put the rest of us out of your misery. You are extremely overpaid for the tiny amount of "work" you do every day.

Pros_y: Chili's really pushed me to self develop. I would not be where I am without them. They give a lot of internal promotions who otherwise could not get management jobs due to lack of experience.
Cons_y: Does not live there company values. Preach to be all about their people but do not follow up with actions. More profit driven based on volume and not creating great guest and team member environments
Advice to Management_y: Work on culture. Live and lead by your core values. In this business loyalty is huge and bulkhead are loyal. Make each of them feel special.

Pros_x: Chili's is great if you are in college or high school and do not have many bills to pay. There is great opportunity for good tips, but I'm sure that varies by location. They have always been good to me and they are typically pretty flexible when it comes to scheduling.
Cons_x: They do not always hire the best employees. Sometimes it seems as if they would hire anyone who walked through the door. Chili's has a TON of promotions and sales that decrease the overall price of a customer's meal, and it also decreases the tip amount if the customer is paying the standard 20%. It would be a terrible place to work if you actually had a lot of bills to pay. There is no overtime.

Pros_x: -Flexible and managers work around your schedule. -Great employee discount! (50% off at every chili's and Maggiano's little Italty, up to four people and 20% gratuity required)
Cons_x: -Managers care strongly on ITR (intent to return), a survey based data that suggests how likely your guests are to return to Chili's. -Inconsistent scheduling, managers will tend to favor old people and give you the worst hours (all closing or opening shifts).
Advice to Management_x: Treat employees like they matter. Have a strong sense of professionalism in the work place and work to maintain a good environment.

Pros_x: Met some of the best people I know while working at Chili's.
Cons_x: The brand is very confused. It is not sure what is wants to be to it's consumers. Working in operations, and then to upper management, there was a stark contrast in reality as to what was expected from the operators. The parameters that are given vs what is expected is just not realistic. Managers would be crying daily because the stress that would be placed on their shoulders was too high. The menu is ridiculously large and impossible to execute properly.
Advice to Management_x: Figure out what kind of restaurant you want to be. Listen to your operators honest feedback. Labor parameters are just too tight to operate a menu with 120 items. The fact that the menu cannot be executed properly and timely is why you are losing guests. And guess what....Bussers help keep your restaurants clean at very minimal cost. Big mistake to eliminate them.

Pros_x: There is never a dull moment. Coworkers almost always become really close friends. Quick and easy money as long as you're invested in doing your job well.
Cons_x: Some coworkers care more about getting in and out of work rather than working as members of a team which is what the job is all about. Not much positive feedback from management... You don't tend to get rewarded or acknowledged for how well you work, but almost always get criticized for less than stellar performance even if you're working hard. Frequent turnover
Advice to Management_x: Spend more time on the floor during busy times rather than hiding out in the kitchen. Create more balance in the support you show to FOH and BOH employees.

The fact that the menu cannot be executed properly and timely is why you are losing guests. And guess what....Bussers help keep your restaurants clean at very minimal cost. Big mistake to eliminate them.

Pros_x: Good money, great crew, and flexible hours
Cons_x: Horrible Managment!!!, Scheduling conflicts, and bad leadership
Advice to Management_x: Don't overwork your good workers and after only give bad workers more hours
Pros_y: Met some of the best people I know while working at Chili's.
Cons_y: The brand is very confused. It is not sure what is wants to be to it's consumers. Working in operations, and then to upper management, there was a stark contrast in reality as to what was expected from the operators. Title_x: "Demanding which is fine but compensation dried up."
Pros_x: Tenured managers/team members cover a lot of work. The tenured ones should be highly valued candidates at other concepts. Company listened briefly when there was a giant pushback by team. Made smart changes that saved money and eased execution.
Cons_x: Corporate chose the shareholders over the employees, then doubled up commitment to shareholders again. Though corporate listened they stopped the employee satisfaction survey saying it was a way administratively to ease the amount of work that was being put on the managers. Many felt it was stopped to not let results be an eye sore for Wall Street to see or to make it harder for hiring new team members.
Advice to Management_x: Smoke and mirror success for quarterly profit but you can't be successful when you forget to truly reward the people that do the work. No respect for "leaders" that leave the company barren.

Pros_x: I enjoyed the large company perks of benefits and at 401k plan along with the fun stuff like christmas parties and company softball tournaments. Most of all I learned how to own up to mistakes and work my butt off with the help of an awesome team behind me. I over all had a positive experience.
Cons_x: I mean besides feeling like a cog in a machine. There were changes made for the sake of change rather than any real benefit. Shared sections because they didn't want to pay as many people to be on the floor. Overall a bunch of little things added up to me not wanting to be there anymore.
Advice to Management_x: Don't forget to take the feedback given. And take care of your servers. The happier they are the more money they will make you. Happy people buy more food.

Pros_x: At store level there is a bond like no other, Much more like a family. Even the high end management will step up and roll their sleeves up and help out.
Cons_x: Very difficult to fire people. If their is a problem employee it takes many write ups to get a termination. When the staff member does finally get fired, it's considered manager failure. ( Interviewer failed, training failure, or we didn't work with the employee closely enough)
Advice to Management_x: Job security is nice, but you need to make sure people know they can't get away with breaking rules without consequences.

Pros_x: With my title it was only pay and life work balance but that was only because I wrote my own schedule. Before our new area director came it was a fun place to work.
Cons_x: Can't pay cooks a proper wage therefore cooks didn't give 100% no raise.when I took the general manager position my page did not jump to what I had expected. I was basically why that would be an extra $10,000 and yet he even broke it down to numbers right in front of me. When I got my first paycheck it was wrong so I went to him and he said it was more bonus based than anything.
Advice to Management_x: Stop the management and employee gossip, the work for you and aren't your so called friends. Also at the store management seemed to talk about other managers behind their back this was the area directors doing. That area director would take credit for a great numbers but anything that went wrong was behind on the management team. I worked there for 16 years, started as a dishwasher and walked my way to the general manager. Our new area director mind you store just closed because of bad numbers all of a sudden becomes our new director. Came in and fired the team managers that work there 16+ years and hired a whole new manager instead even though the numbers were the best they've ever been. Basically boils down to if he didn't like you or you didn't kiss his butt you were gone.

Pros_x: The direct team and area I work alongside are great! The company promotes from within and that's great ! You can make a great living from this company. What you put in is what you get out.
Cons_x: The business model is broken. Squeezing the life out of everyone does not grow a business. There's reasons why Texas Roadhouse, Olive Garden , red lobster, and cheddars are more liked. They give better service because they have less tables , bussers, and their labor plans allow for business growth.
Advice to Management_x: It's no coincidence that a company of 900+ restaurants are "slow and cold ". The problem is the business model and system. Until that's recognized you have to be satisfied with being a mediocre company.

Cons_y: The business model is broken. Squeezing the life out of everyone does not grow a business. There's reasons why Texas Roadhouse, Olive Garden , red lobster, and cheddars are more liked. They give better service because they have less tables , bussers, and their labor plans allow for business growth.
Advice to Management_y: It's no coincidence that a company of 900+ restaurants are "slow and cold ". The problem is the business model and system. Until that's recognized you have to be satisfied with being a mediocre company.

Pros_x: Working with a great team. Team service is usually great. Managers help on the floor and in the kitchen. And usuall no silverwear rolling!
Cons_x: ITR! Survey guest take after paying on ziosk or online are your job and main problem. Spending hours trying to get a 5 on one question is terriable. Once something goes wrong (cold food, weak drink, long door wait) it will probably lower your itr score. It dont matter if it is ther servers fult or not. If your score goes under a 67% you only have a couple weeks to redeem yourself before you get fired.
Advice to Management_x: It wouldnt be so bad if we went constantly reminded that we may lose our job if we dont get surveys .. A 5 at that.. No 4s .. Only 5s.. Its a rolling score. We have good and bad days .. We are human and its impossible to keep every single person happy. I can say the most of our staff takes pride in our work and make a strong effort to make every guest feel welcome and special. Its a shame to see a company lose so many great servers over this. Maybe management could have a meeting to talk to corporate.

Title_x: "Do not work here. You've been warned."
Pros_x: You make cool friends, 50% off, semi flexible schedule, meet good people, 50% off food.
Cons_x: Managers don't care about employees, corporate only wants to make more money. Hence the new team service evolution. It sucks. Turn servers into food runners only and remove togo and qa completely. Thanks for your 10 years + of service with our company but your no longer needed.
Advice to Management_x: Advice for corporate, Listen to your employees who have been faithful to your company for 10+ years. Don't throw them out like stale bread. When everyone else was quitting after 2 months of putting up with your crap, the veterans of your company stuck by your side, worked ridiculous hours and every holiday. Treat them right.

Pros_x: Good money for good work I've been with chilis for two years and have enough to support me and my family.
Cons_x: Management cares more about the surveys intent to return. Schedules meeting for people below 75% and doesn't allow them to clock in. Also can be taken off schedule for low survey numbers. Really hard to keep above 75% when a 5 stars is 100% 4 is 0% and anything below brings you to negatives. This company is all about numbers.
Advice to Management_x: Schedule people on skill instead of their numbers.

They want hostess to bust tables and seat people. Most of the time you are up there by yourself and I was still in training. All the customers complain about the food.
Advice to Management_x: We are the only restaurant on the strip that's not busy on Friday night. Change that.

Pros_x: I like my coworkers. I like my bosses. The perks of discounted or free food is always appreciated and i recieve highly valued services and special treatements from other businesses because they consider me an "insider". The money I earn can be considered easy and fast.
Cons_x: The work is hard. The hours are long. The conditions can be terrible. There is no such thing as a lunch break in the restaurant industry (even if I am scheduled all day) and the pay is under mininum wage. I joke about this constently. The stress level can be through the roof. Sometimes the customer can be stressors, sometimes coworkers can be stressors, and sometimes my managers can be stressors. The entire work shift can be considered slow, boring, and a waste of my time or overwhelming and not properly backed up by my team or supplies. Every day is something different. The hardest part fo the job title for me is to be able to take care of yourself in times where you may feel obligated to help others, Sometimes when working as a group or in a team everyone must do their best to focus on their job because one weak link can slow the entire group down. Nobody can afford to help someone swim so you have to let them drown or learn to tred on their own. I learned this the hard way, by helping others I took away from my own guests and their attentative needs, This resulted in poor survey results which dictated my scheduling. So even though I was helping all my coworkers and taking one for the team, when it came to my pockets for the shift, I was then hurt again by the lack of hours scheduled to me because of my poor customer intention to return survey results.
Advice to Management_x: Use discretion

Title_x: "Very enjoyabke until they stab you in the back"
Pros_x: Salary, bonuses, vacations are all very nice. You also get christmas and thanksgiving off.
Cons_x: Give many employees off at the same time leaving minimum staff. You do all of the general managers work. They believe everything the employees say when they retaliate against you are the one that gets fired.
Advice to Management_x: Do onto others as you would have them do onto you. Your mee surveys are not annonymous for managers since we have to put how long we work their and if we are male or female so we cannot say when fellow managers or general manager is incompetent or not doing their job. Quick to sweep things under the rug.

Pros_x: Great place to be. Fun atmosphere . Moving up the ladder is easy. Co-workers become family. Easy money. Cash in hand every night including tip share for bartenders. Great starting point for first time servers. Always hiring.
Cons_x: No bussers. No food runners. Very little Q/As because the pay isn't worth it. When your location isn't fully staffed, you end up doing multiple jobs outside of your own. Big concern on survey responses without proper support.
Advice to Management_x: Chilies has lost it way with the focus to make a profit. Go back to the basics. Make your Q/As more valued and bring back bussers and food runners if your intent is to have a great guest return rate. Servers are the least paid and do the most work. We make our living by the service we provide which is also how your intent to return rate, sales, and bonuses improve. Without Servers, there is no service.

Pros_x: I work with some amazing people. Throughout my tenure with Chilis, I've learned that most of the best managers are strong individuals that defy corporate culture and truly make the work place meaningful.
Cons_x: Massive wage theft.. . As I write this, a coworker is currently setting the restaurant up for business. This employee is not clocked in. They have been doing this for five or six days a week for going on four years. This person has even received several ATL (above the line) comments from former GMs and ADs.. . Very tight run company. Employees are often asked to pick up product from other locations because we run out. They usually on their way to work and not on the clock while this happens.. . Not salary competitive. Most employees, hosts especially, can receive better pay and less work from other companies.
Advice to Management_x: Chilis looks great on paper. Stop being disengaged with your guests and employees. Actually try performing the tasks you ask your hourly and salaried employees to do.

Title_x: "Great job not so great employees or food."
Pros_x: Great head manager and some great normal managers. Flexible with your schedules, positions and location. Alright wage.
Cons_x: Guests can be rude although it comes with the job. Server who worked their long was unethical. For example he was sit more guests in his area for money, would hate if guests asked for their own spot, which we had a argument with letting the guests always be right. He was just selfish to our employees and guests. You get fired if you hang out with employees, which happened with on of my bosses. Of course you can not eat the food while working.
Advice to Management_x: Definitely need better food.
Pros_y: Great pay, room for advancement and benefits
Cons_y: Work life balance isn't great

Pros_x: Was a great place to work at one point, room for advancement, good culture, attempt at work life balance, Wellbeing
Cons_x: Lost sight of a lot of things. Culture lead to complacency in terms of accountability, tough to find good help, the jobs were HARD, every position was a pressure cooker(but paid well, golden handcuffs if you will). Need to be "relevant" lead to way too many/too often changes, making it impossible to hone your craft and be great.
Advice to Management_x: Back to basics.
Pros_y: Great pay, room for advancement and benefits
Cons_y: Work life balance isn't great

Pros_x: Being an ALL American grill, you get exposed to diverse people, and thus, diverse cultures. Tips are good if you find an ideal location. Also, there is flexibility to work certain days and not others, which has made going to college a bit easier.
Cons_x: Long, and late hours. Sometimes getting off work at 12am and having to be back to work at 10:30am sucks--especially if you have class the next day. My sleep cycles have not been consistent as a direct result of working at a restaurant that closes at 10 and 11 on Friday and Saturday. It's hard to complain though when you see the nicest management team all working 80+ hours a week.
Advice to Management_x: Keep up your hard work! The team would suffer if it weren't for your guidance and support. Keep asking for pay raises--cause they certainty deserve it.
Pros_y: Great pay, room for advancement and benefits
Cons_y: Work life balance isn't great

Pros_x: Flexible schedule, cool people to work with.

Pros_x: the pay and benefits are good
Cons_x: stress level and work loads are real

Cons_y: Work life balance isn't great

Pros_x: The company that owns Chili's (Brinker Nation) is a well run, and organized company. The continue to lead the casual dining category. The have the best food out of all the companies in this category by far.
Cons_x: The company places unrealistic criteria on the serving staff. Requiring a certain percentage of people to answer a survey at the end of the meal. The use a 5 point scale for these survey questions. If any customer answers anything but a 5 on any of the questions, it is then perceived negatively on the servers and management.
Advice to Management_x: Place a higher importance on hiring quality staff.
Pros_y: Great pay, room for advancement and benefits
Cons_y: Work life balance isn't great

Pros_x: Great team oriented staff always willing to help.
Cons_x: Scheduling was a disaster. I found myself closing 5 nights a week with 20+ other servers on staff. Business model attracts horrible clientele which in turn decreases tip production.
Advice to Management_x: Schedule fairly and possibly produce new marketing initiatives which place some sort of focus on your employees.

Advice to Management_x: Pay attention to guest trends and comments. Healthy eating might seem smart but an awesome blossom wins hearts and minds. Choose better General Managers and treat all managers better. Fire GM's that lose long standing vetetans, that's a sign: Pay Attention.

Cons_y: Work life balance isn't great

Pros_x: They will work around your schedule. Some shifts are really worth it. Most of the people you work with are great. Some of the customers are great.
Cons_x: You work your butt off every shift. You are not guaranteed to make money. There have been many shifts that I made less than minimum wage. It is a very high stress job. Many customers don't tip at all. Many more customers tip very little. Your schedule is different from day to day and week to week. You may not know your schedule more than a few days ahead. Just because you are scheduled for a specific section for the night does not always mean that is what will happen, beware of last minute changes, without your knowledge.
Advice to Management_x: Having more than a 2 day notice for my schedule would be great, especially for those who have other obligations and/or children to consider. Gratuity for large parties should be mandatory. I've had too many groups who run you ragged, and leave you nothing for your time.
Pros_y: Great pay, room for advancement and benefits
Cons_y: Work life balance isn't great

Pros_x: It is good money and usually pretty fun environment.

Pros_x: Good vacations after 10+ years. Quarterly bonuses
Cons_x: Salaried managers work long hours 60-80hr weeks at times, turn around shifts, doubles. These long hours make home life very difficult. Management team is forced to understaff hourly team members to achieve numbers almost always resulting in manager stepping in to these roles versus focusing on customer service/satisfaction.
Advice to Management_x: Focus more on staffing up for an excellent experience for your guests and not running management/hourly team members ragged.

Pros_x: Meal discounts, 50% off shift meal, and you also receive a discount card for 50% off at any Chili's. Friendly managers. Easy to request off (two weeks advance notice)
Cons_x: Not really worth the minimum wage. Chili's does not have bussers, so as a host, I had to bus tables while also tending to the front door. It's really stressful when you're on a wait, as the servers aren't very apt to pre-bussing their tables. There is no tip share and the servers won't tip you out, no matter how many of their tables you end up bussing.. The host positions are hellishly understaffed. There's typically only one host per shift, unless it's a Friday night or Sunday morning.
Pros_y: Love the culture and the team members
Cons_y: High stress and late hours

Pros_x: Flexible schedule, maximize income in short time, meet life long friends. 401k, yearly bonus if you averaged 30 hours, part time and full time insurance offered.
Cons_x: Income can fluctuate so budget for slow times, no paid vacations on yearly bonus, unlimited time off if you want but with no income
Advice to Management_x: Hold everyone accountable. Don't expect more from the workers and less from the lazy workers. Consistency is key.
Pros_y: they encourage a great quality of life!. schedule requests are honored as much as possible
Cons_y: running shifts with bare bone staff can get stressful

Pros_x: Some of the people that work for the company really try to adhere to the Business Model of ERJ Dining or Chili's
Cons_x: There are too many to list them all but the majority of upper management are hypocritical and will say one thing to your face and then when their boss is touring with them, they will act as if they agree with all directives. Upper management can often let their tempers get the best of them and the company uses religion to cover up the many character flaws or its people which include blaming those down the management team structure, a lack of knowledge on what it means to run a restaurant leading to ridiculous expectations that are used subjectively at every store depending on how much upper management gets along with that Management Team or how much money they make for those above them. There is a lack of respect for tenure and it actually tends to harm a lot of middle management because they will find a reason to replace you if you are making too much money. The company has a lack of understanding of the communities it serves and holds all restaurants to the same goals in turnover regardless of the workforce available to the area. Retaliation often occurs in this company keeping its employees to present their true problems and feelings. Assistant managers are in and out of the stores almost as much as the hourly employees because the training program is not holding everyone to the same level of accountability causing the stores to be short staffed so much so that everyone is expected to travel to guest manage at stores that are up to 80 miles from their home.
Advice to Management_x: Follow your Inverted Pyramid, Don't be naive to think that your Regional Managers are all doing their jobs with the morals and ethics that The person who started this once great company expects of his employees. Stop sweeping problems under the rug by moving managers from one store where they create an issue to another store thinking that the person will change. Take harassment, both sexual and verbal, seriously and understand that it occurs in the restaurants today as I type by a number of managers including your training stores.
Pros_y: they encourage a great quality of life!. schedule requests are honored as much as possible
Cons_y: running shifts with bare bone staff can get stressful

Pros_x: Great environment! Team work always!
Cons_x: ITR can ruin how your scheduled.
Advice to Management_x: Look into your employees

Pros_x: Our location was always busy and recently renovated. Most of the people working are really motivated so its a nice work environment that way.
Cons_x: Restaurant is understaffed usually, leading to unnecessary stress for all workers both FOH and BOH. They should hire bussers/food runners etc. but I guess it would cost them too much. Also technology wise the restaurant is behind others of the same brand (applebees,cpk etc.) The host are still using a white board for their floor plan. Also reward your staff a little more, free meals, incentives might keep people with the company longer.

Pros_x: Potential to have larger sections compared to other restaurants.. Our store often had contests to win gift cards and other perks!
Cons_x: SECTION PARTNERS!!!! Sharing a zone was horrible! You would alternate with another server, sometimes leaving you with a bunch of two-tops and your partner with all of the large parties. Splitting sidework never worked well either. Don't expect great tips from this customer market!

Title_x: "A great restaurant to work for with a fun atmosphere!"
Pros_x: The discount was my favorite part of working there due to Chili's serving some of my favorite foods, but they offer many more other perks and benefits such as health insurance, 401K, and paid time off. The work atmosphere was nice and for the most part I usually enjoyed going in to work because I knew what to expect and if I ever had a problem, the management would always try to help resolve them.
Cons_x: Since it is the restaurant industry, there was sometimes unnecessary and unwanted drama due to the coworkers lifestyles and the relationships that stem from working in such an environment.
Advice to Management_x: Don't allow dramatic or sensitive conversations to take place at work or during working hours.

Cons_y: Training lack of future development not on board with other retailers

Pros_x: It was a corporate environment, so if that is what you are looking for, then it's not bad. Good for college students or people right out of high school who need some training before they move on to something better.
Cons_x: The management was not very effective. The cooks basically had the run of the kitchen, and if the people who had been there longest didn't like you, then they took it out on you by throwing the food you make in the trash, yelling, shoulder checks, etc.
Advice to Management_x: You need to be more consistent as managers, and fire people when they are rude to other employees, especially when it hits the point of getting physical.

Title_x: "Working at Chilis has been like a roller coaster."
Pros_x: Quality of life has been great. You can earn up to 4 vacations a year depending on your tenure. Have made a lot of great friends working here.

Advice to Management_x: Take care of your people better.

Pros_x: The atmosphere is great. Chilis is literally like family as far as being employed there. Thy always have fundraising events, not just for ST Jude but other organizations, which is awesome. The food is pretty good and they are going more and more fresh with their products which is great, and with the new theme of hot and fast if you can get fresh hot and fast that's great.
Cons_x: Menu changes too frequently, change is good, down sizing is good but they should put out some type of advertisement informing customers. With the new down size we just did, yes we inform our customers and obviously the menu immediately looks different, but you have tables that will get up and leave if we no longer offer what they do. They also are constantly switching up how you do things as an employee. It's hard to keep up and. I've been with the company for 4 years.

Title_x: "Alright, but not a place to stay"
Pros_x: Free food. Fifty percent off on to go food after your shifts. Good pay, around $80 average a shift. Short hours. Around five or six hour shifts will make you that. Could go up to $120 or more, depending on day and busyness. Management was eh, but doable. I worked at one restaurant in TN and one in SC. The one in SC was just awful, everything good I've said about this company was from TN and was connected with Brinker.
Cons_x: Terrible management (SC). Every order I would put in would be made wrong by kitchen that just didn't care about anything.. Short staffed all the time.. Employees of all kinds, even management would stand around talking in the middle of a rush.
Pros_y: Good benefits, good peers to use as resources
Cons_y: Company changing, not as people oriented as in the past

Title_x: "It’s not bad but it’s a lot of work for little pay."
Pros_x: Your coworker make it worth staying, plus you get benefits and vacation pay after a year. It’s not a bad company to work for. Most are flexible with scheduling.
Cons_x: Cleaning, annoying customers, sometimes throwing you to the wolves without enough training, working with petty people who don’t always speak English
Pros_y: Good benefits, good peers to use as resources
Cons_y: Company changing, not as people oriented as in the past

Pros_x: Some people were great. Regular guests made everything worth it. Organizational flow is not horrible. I worked for a franchise.
Cons_x: The franchise I worked for is constantly hemorrhaging both staff and management. It’s tough. I was sent to a store with a GM who was allowed to run the store into the ground. No amount of effort will make that store what it was in its heyday. As a management team, we never bonused.

Pros_x: ( Might vary ). Great team members. Lots of fun moments. personal management. MANY company programs ranging from reimbursement for child care and smoking cessation, to huge discounts of just about anything you can buy (and many more). Great starting wage comparatively to the restaurant industry. Also, consumer wise VERY clean and well maintained restaurant, probably the best in those terms in the industry.
Cons_x: Part of chilis business model is doing more with less, you'll earn around $10-12 starting wage but must do a wide degree of tasks and in large amounts.. Lack of order and organazation
Advice to Management_x: Managers are people too (surprise), but please exercise more patience and do not take frustration out on everyone. Hold equal standards to all, instead of delegating the most demanding tasks to the select few "good" employees (happens 100% of the time) and enforce more organization.

Title_x: "Opinions based on a few of the Puerto Rico's Chili's establishments"
Pros_x: Teamworked is promoted, you learn to multi-task and work in a fast-paced environment under a lot of pressure, flexible change of position you work in (i.e going from Busser to Waiter, Cook to Expo, etc. Though this also depends on how short staffed they are in certain positions), end of the year bonus depend on the hours you made thoughout the year.
Cons_x: Most managers are lazy, employees are overworked for very mediocre wage, if you're really good at whatever position (really good dishwasher, cook, etc.), chance of position transfer is slim, good employees often times are treated wrongly (yelled at unfairly or overworked while mediocre employees stand around not doing much).
Advice to Management_x: Treat your good workers right and crack the whip on the mediocre ones so there's more efficient workers and teamwork.
Pros_y: Some people were great. Regular guests made everything worth it. Organizational flow is not horrible. I worked for a franchise.
Cons_y: The franchise I worked for is constantly hemorrhaging both staff and management. It’s tough. I was sent to a store with a GM who was allowed to run the store into the ground. No amount of effort will make that store what it was in its heyday. As a management team, we never bonused.

Cons_y: The franchise I worked for is constantly hemorrhaging both staff and management. It’s tough. I was sent to a store with a GM who was allowed to run the store into the ground. No amount of effort will make that store what it was in its heyday. As a management team, we never bonused.

Pros_x: Great Management, Great work atmosphere
Cons_x: lack of interest in work from fellow coworkers
Advice to Management_x: work on kitchen staff
Pros_y: Fast paced and a very hands on experience in this field.The staff is the main reason I truly enjoy my job...
Cons_y: Turnover is very challenging and a constant problem especially when needing to do a schedule... availability is a constant problem
Advice to Management_y: Establish yourself and your expectations from the get...do not play favorites with staff and you should be fine

Pros_x: The money is good if you're willing to work for it.
Cons_x: Sometimes management could be a little more consistent with accountability.
Advice to Management_x: Pay attention. Appreciate the people that work hard for you. If you take care of team members, they take care of guests, and the bottom line takes care of itself. Accountability should be across the board. It's never an option.

Pros_x: Some coworkers are hardworking and make it enjoyable. When I was asked to stay longer, pick up extra shifts, or work elsewhere (ex go to host or to go even though I was a server at the time) the managers would give me free meals
Cons_x: The location I worked at had a high turnover rate among employees leading those of us there to pick up the slack. I started as a hostess while in high school but then became a server. Since hosts and to go specialists would quit I would fill in. Also short staffed on servers would make it to where the most experienced servers would work all day Saturday. I would go in at 1 and be a closer with no break. I was a swing and should have been first cut but this was consistently done every Saturday for months. They would not trust other servers to close.
Pros_y: continuous work, keeps you busy
Cons_y: don't do background checks so you get a lot of not honest people upper management too

Love them all... the only advice is to just hire a diswasher for day time who can take out trash and do dishes so the Prep guy can focus on prep!

Title_x: "I started as a hostess and moved up to server"
Pros_x: Flexible schedule, fast paced, 50% off food after 3 months of being an employee
Cons_x: Rude customers, If you are a server you are given shifts based on ITR (Intent to return) surveys that customers take at the end when paying out.
Pros_y: They are one of the higher paying chains in the area
Cons_y: Area management and above is horrible, turnover for management in general is extremely high. Quality of life is some of the worst in the field.

Pros_x: Fun Job with Food. Great Atmosphere. Flexible Scheduling
Cons_x: Management had high turnover rate
Pros_y: They are one of the higher paying chains in the area
Cons_y: Area management and above is horrible, turnover for management in general is extremely high. Quality of life is some of the worst in the field.

Pros_x: Busy restaurant with high guest turnover provides ample opportunity to make great money.
Cons_x: Managers expect you to perform at optimum levels to receive positive GEM scores (surveys on the ziosks) but don't provide their staff with the tools and support needed to recognize these goals. Improper ordering causes shortages of certain menu and promotional items and inadequate support when the staff is in need; hiding in the office while both front and back of house employees fall behind.
Advice to Management_x: Provide adequate training to employees instead of giving them 3 days of shadowing and then throwing them to the wolves and then Reprimanding them for their poor performance/survey results. Step out of the office and behind the line to cook or up front running food, etc. as needed. Stop attempting to cut corners on ordering product to ensure all menu items are consistently available to ensure guest satisfaction.
Pros_y: They are one of the higher paying chains in the area
Cons_y: Area management and above is horrible, turnover for management in general is extremely high. Quality of life is some of the worst in the field.

Pros_x: Flexible schedule, good money, easy
Cons_x: Lack of real career opportunities
Advice to Management_x: Reward hard working employees
Pros_y: Developed great friendships. Awesome training program.
Cons_y: Changed in a lot of ways. Went from Quality of service to Quantity of Guest.
Advice to Management_y: Brink Back the Brinker that was about taking care of people.

Pros_x: Free lunch/ dinner meal on shift for cooks
Cons_x: Had to work non stop at a fast pace, constantly remaking food for incorrect orders.
Advice to Management_x: don't keep your chefs late all week cleaning and then cut their hours at the end of the week and end up short staffed

Pros_x: Discounts on certain food items, free fries, free drinks, and free chips and salsa. Cash on hand every night. Some Co-workers were decent
Cons_x: Training isn’t detailed. Stressful. Manager don’t know how to talk to their workers.. . Barely learned anything during the training process besides how to wait on a table. My second day of working on my own, I was given a table of 15 on an already busy day (Veterans Day) the managers were very unhelpful and rude that made me want to walk out and quit that day. I wasn’t making a lot of money on my shifts because I’d always be sent home within the first 2 hours of working with only 3-4 tables each shift. Where others where making $100+ a shift, I only made $20. Some days they’d put me back as a trainee to help me with the issues I was having (something that I should’ve learned within the first 5 days but hadn’t) last week when the schedules were being made, I didn’t receive one. Tried to pick up a shift, it got denied because “no”. Was contacted by the manager saying I was going to be retraining and asked what position I’d like to work in the restaurant. I replied, no response. Another schedule has been put out and I’m still not scheduled. Despite my mistakes from a lack of knowledge, I was better than some who had been there for months so I assume they’re trying to force me to quit
Advice to Management_x: Y’all are trash
Pros_y: Developed great friendships. Awesome training program.
Cons_y: Changed in a lot of ways. Went from Quality of service to Quantity of Guest.
Advice to Management_y: Brink Back the Brinker that was about taking care of people.

Cons_x: No way to give good service. Employees are encouraged to rip off customers all in the name of AvT. Greedy managers. I watched managers swap top shelf liquor for cheap well in order to have lower liquor cost. Watched Managers drink and do drugs on duty. Managers regularly used B.o.g’s to take take cash from cash checks. Watched back of house guys smoke pot on the back dock with door open. Drug use in the open and managers just laughed about it. Servers caught serving under age and allowed to keep working. Servers were allowed to confront guests about poor tips. Its like the wild west.
Advice to Management_x: Treat others how you want to be treated.
Pros_y: Developed great friendships. Awesome training program.
Cons_y: Changed in a lot of ways. Went from Quality of service to Quantity of Guest.
Advice to Management_y: Brink Back the Brinker that was about taking care of people.
